questions.text: ________ scientist introduced vaccine for Smallpox vaccine
questions.solution:
In 1796 Edward Jenner discovered Smallpox vaccine
First Vaccine discovered was Smallpox vaccine
– Smallpox is the ‘First and Only’ disease to be eradicated
– Edward Jenner coined the term ‘Vaccination’

questions.text: Socialized medicine is?

choices.text: Integration of social medicine with health care
Free medical care at government expense, regulated by professional groups

questions.solution:
• State Medicine: Provision of free medical services to the people at government expense
• Socialized Medicine: Provision of medical service and professional education by the State (as
in state medicine), but the
programme is operated and regulated by professional groups rather than by government
– Provision of medical services supported by state government
– Prevents competition between practitioners and clients
— Ensures social equity that is universally operated by professional health services
• Social Medicine: Study of the social, economical, environmental, psychological and genetic
factors

questions.text: All of the following are common cause of post neonatalinfant mortality in India, except?
questions.solution:
NEONATAL MORTALITY RATE (NNMR):
• Most common cause of NNMR in INDIA is preterm birth
• Most common cause of LNNMR:-Infections (diarrhea and tetanus)
• Neonatal mortality is the ‘most difficult’ part of infant mortality rate to alter

questions.text: All are true about Rashtriya Swasthya Bima Yojana, except?
questions.solution:
• Synonym:-National Health Insurance Scheme
• Beneficiaries:-Below poverty line families
• Contribution:– Central government: INR 600/-
– State Government: INR 200 (25% of total)
-Benefits:– Inpatient medical cover per family per year:-INR 30,000/-
– family member death cover:-INR 25,000/-

questions.text: Patient was given chloroquine and doxycycline for 7 days. Pt fever decline in 4 days butpt peripheral smear showed gametocytes of Plasmodium falciparum. This is which type of drugresistance?
questions.solution:
Types of Drug Resistance in Malaria
• type R1 resistance:-Recrudescence of infection between 7-28 days of treatment completion
following initial resolution of symptoms and parasite clearance.
• type R2 resistance: -Pt with marked reduction of parasitemia at 48hr but failed to clear
parasites by day seven

questions.text: Which of the below statement is not true about cohort study ?

choices.text: Indicated when there is good evidence of association between exposure and disease
Done when incidence of disease is very low among exposed
Done when ample funds are available

questions.solution:
• Case control study is preferable for rare diseases
: Cohort study IS NOT USEFUL to investigate rare diseases as whole time,
and expense may yield little/ no disease, thus strength of association may not be calculable
• COHORT STUDY IS BETTER THAN CASE CONTROL STUDY (even with the issues of ethics,
attrition)
: As Relative risk is a better estimate of strength of association than Odds ratio

questions.text: Among the following which is the non-essential micronutrient?
questions.solution:
• Macronutrients: Proximate Principles which form the bulk of the diet
– Carbohydrates
– Fats
– Proteins
• Micronutrients: Vitamin and Minerals (in small quantities)
-Major minerals: Sodium, Potassium, Magnesium, Calcium, Phosphorus
Trace elements: Iron, Iodine, Fluorine, Zinc, Copper, Cobalt, Selenium, Chromium, Manganese,
Molybdenum,Nickel, Tin, Silicon, Vanadium
-Trace contaminant with no known function in body: Lead, Mercury, Barium, Boron, Aluminium

questions.text: The eye condition for which the World Bank assistance was provided to the NationalProgramme for Control of Blindness (1994-2001) is:
questions.solution:
• Most common cause of blindness in India is Cataract
• Cataract is included among target diseases in Vision 2020 (both Globally and Indian)
• National Programme for Control of Blindness (NPCB) was started in 1976 as a 100% centrally
sponsored scheme

• Strategies of NPCB include establishing ‘one eye care facility per 5 lac
persons’
– DANISH assistance to NPCB (Manpower development, Establishment of management system
at state level, Establishment & development of monitoring and evaluation system, Preparation
of health education material, teaching and information aids, Training)

questions.text: Which of the following Health organisation is not a part of Vision 2020 ?

choices.text: International Agency for Prevention of Blindness

questions.solution:
• International organisations involved in Vision 2020:
– WHO
– International Eye Foundation
– International Federation for Ophthalmological Societies – International Organisation against
Trachoma
– Rotary International
– World Blind Union
– World Council of Optometry
– Helen Keller International
Etc

questions.text: Amniocentesis to detect chromosomal abnormalities
questions.solution:
Amniocentesis: examination of a sample of amniotic fluid makes possible the prenataldiagnosis of chromosomal
anomalies and certain metabolic defects; the procedure can be used as early as 14th week of
pregnancy when abortion of affected fetus is still feasible

– Culture and karyotyping of fetal cells from amniotic fluid is used for diagnosis of fetal
anomalies
– Biochemical analysis of amniotic fluid is used for diagnosis of metabolic effects
• Amniocentesis is indicated in following circumstances:
– A mother aged > 35 years (high risk of down’s syndrome)
– Patients who have had a child with down’s syndrome or other chromosomal anomalies –
Parents known to have chromosomal translocation
– Patients who have had a child with metabolic defect
– when sex-determination is warranted

questions.text: Identify the symbol given in Below image ?
The criteria to diagnose hypereosinophilic syndrome include all of the following EXCEPT:

choices.text: Increased bone marrow eosinophils must be shown
Increased circulating eosinophils are not necessary
Exclusion of Primary myeloid leukemia is required

questions.solution:
• Diagnostic criteria for chronic eosinophilic leukemia and hypereosinophilic syndrome:
  • Presence of persistent eosinophilia ≥1500/μL in blood
  • increased marrow eosinophils
  • <20% myeloblasts in blood or marrow
  • Exclusion of:
    • Reactive eosinophilia
    • primary neoplasms with eosinophilia (e.g., T-cell lymphoma, Hodgkin disease, ALL, mastocytosis, CML, AML, myelodysplasia, myeloproliferative syndromes)
    • T-cell reaction with increased IL-5 or cytokine production.

questions.text: A 20 year old man with a k/c/o sickle cell anemia presents to the ER with diffuse body pain, dyspnea, fever, and cough. He complained of having a bone pain crisis a day before which he tried to treat at home with oral hydration. On examination: raised blood pressure and heart rate, respiratory discomfort. SaO2: 83% —> increases to 91% on a non rebreather O2 face mask. CXR shows bilateral diffuse alveolar infiltrates. This is his third similar presentation in the past year. Which of the following statements are false regarding his condition?

choices.text: Chronic therapy with oral hydroxyurea should be administered
The patient should receive daily sildenafil

questions.solution:
• Acute chest syndrome: is characterized by:
    • chest pain
    • tachypnea
    • fever
    • cough
    • arterial oxygen desaturation
    • mimics pneumonia, pulmonary emboli, bone marrow infarction and embolism, myocardial ischemia, or in situ lung infarction.
  • Trials of sildenafil to restore NO2 levels: terminated due to adverse effects.

questions.text: In a 30 year old woman with idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP), which of the following characteristics would be expected?
questions.solution:
• Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura: increased peripheral platelet destruction and/or reduction in bone marrow platelet production.
  • The main symptom: bleeding, including ecchymosis and Petechiae.
  • Hence, presence of abnormal bruising would be present in this patient.

questions.text: The resulting fractions of a blood test to reveal a hematocrit value are which of the following?

choices.text: Plasma, buffy coat, and packed erythrocytes
Fibrinogen, platelets, buffy coat, and erythrocytes

questions.solution:
• Blood is removed from the body—> clot formation with platelets, RBCs, WBCs, and serum.
  • Hematocrit: volume of RBCs per unit volume of blood (40 to 50% in adult human males).
  • On centrifugation with anticoagulants —> blood separates into 3 layers.
  • Uppermost layer is plasma
  • Buffy coat is thin white layer of WBCs found beneath the plasma layer
  • Packed RBC layer at the bottom of the tube.

questions.text: An 18 month old flexes her great toe towards the top of her foot and the other toes fan out. This happens after the sole of her foot has been firmly stroked by the doctor. A year later, this response wasn't seen. This change in response is because of which of the following events, postnatally?

choices.text: Myelination of the corticospinal tract by oligodendrocytes
Myelination of the lumbar spinal nerves by Schwann cells
Apoptosis of exuberant neurons in the cortex by microglia

questions.solution:
• Babinski sign or extensor plantar reflex: an infantile reflex normally present in children until the age of two years
  • Abnormal in older children or adults.
  • Indication of immaturity of the corticospinal tract

questions.text: A 62 year old man presents to the ER with sudden trouble speaking. On physical examination, he speaks slowly and deliberately, but he possesses good comprehension of what is being said. He appears to have weakness of the right lower side of his face and right arm. On further investigation, it is noted that these are signs of a brain infarct. What is the most likely cause of this event?
questions.solution:
• Broca speech area lesion:
    • dominant frontal lobe involvement
    • nonfluent (motor or expressive) aphasia
    • patient speaks slowly and with effort
    • Patient has good comprehension of spoken and written language
    • Focal occlusion by a thrombus of the middle cerebral artery can cause this.

questions.text: A Lewy body disease, Shy-Drager syndrome, is a disease characterized by orthostatic hypotension, impotence, abnormal sweating, hypersalivation, and pupil abnormalities. What is the major component of Lewy bodies, of the following options?
questions.solution:
• Lewy bodies:
    • intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions
    • Made up of fine filaments that are densely packed in the core but loose at their rim.
    • These filaments are composed of:
      • alpha-synuclein (main component)
      • parkin
      • ubiquitin
      • neurofilament antigens

questions.text: Workup of a 58 year old patient, who presents with fever and loss of weight, finds a lesion of the lower spinal cord lesion that destroys both the bone and the cartilage. This abnormality is caused by which of the following?
questions.solution:
• Characteristic of TB: Destruction of intervertebral disks and adjacent vertebral bodies (Potts disease)
  • This causes the bone to collapse, may result in angular kyphosis or scoliosis.

questions.text: In a 32 year old runner, there is a presentation of pain in the plantar portion of her foot between the third and fourth metatarsal bones. Which is the most likely cause of this foot pain?
questions.solution:
• A type of compression neuropathy: associated with a painful swelling of the plantar digital nerve between the second and third or the third and fourth metatarsal bones.
  • This lesion, a Morton neuroma, is mostly found in females.

questions.text: A 52 year old woman presents with headaches and progressively reducing vision over the past few months. Her relatives state that she does not see them when they aren’t directly in front of her and has been bumping into things recently. Physical examination: is unremarkable, other than the visual field defect shown below. A tumor in which of the following anatomical areas would result in these symptoms?
questions.solution:
• The visual pathway —> extends from retina —> through optic nerve —> optic chiasm —> through optic tract —> through lateral geniculate body —> through optic radiations of the temporal and parietal lobes —> to end in the occipital lobes.
  • Bitemporal hemianopsia (seen in the image) is produced by lesions that involve the optic chiasm (anterior to the diaphragmatic sellae of the pituitary gland).

questions.text: A 22 year old woman presents with increased abdominal girth of 3 months in duration. Physical examination shows ascites. On pelvic examination: 7.2cm right ovarian mass,which is removed at surgery. The histologic appearance of this neoplasm most closely resembles which of the following malignant neoplasms seen in men?
questions.solution:
• Dysgerminoma: ovarian counterpart of testicular seminoma
  • Composed of activated germ cells.
  • The neoplasm (image) shows:
    • large nests of monotonously uniform cells
    • Clear glycogen-filled cytoplasm
    • irregularly flattened central nuclei.
    • Fibrous septa containing lymphocytes cross the tumor.

questions.text: A 5 month old male infant is brought to the ER for evaluation of altered behavior and cyanosis. On examination, he has flaccid muscle tone and is taking shallow respirations. No preceding fever, cough, coryza, rash, or new medications; uncomplicated pre- and antenatal course. His diet: soft and pureed foods including yogurt, pureed vegetables, and bananas with added honey. No scheduled vaccinations within the past month. Deep tendon reflexes: absent. Most likely cause of his presentation is?
questions.solution:
- Botulinum toxicity:

- flaccid paralysis

- inhibitor of presynaptic acetylcholine release.

- Honey ingestion, risk factor in infants

questions.text: A woman dies of a chronic neurodegenerative disease. Spongiform encephalopathy with brain amyloidosis is seen on autopsy. This patient’s amyloidosis likely belongs to which of the following categorizations?
questions.solution:
• Spongiform encephalopathy:
    • APrP amyloid
  • Prion proteins (PrPs):
    • natural plasma membrane
    • found in the CNS.
  • PrP:
    • Is a template for association of PrP molecules
    • Makes a new PrP conformation (PrPsc)
  • PrPsc and its aggregates:
    • form fibrils with characteristics of amyloid
    • Seen in central nervous system degenerative diseases, like Kuru, Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, Gerstmann-Straussler-Sheinker disease, scrapie, and bovine spongiform encephalopathy.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is treated for recurrent fractures of his long bones. Physical examination reveals blue sclerae, loose joints, abnormal teeth, and poor hearing. Molecular diagnostic stud- ies will most likely demonstrate a mutation in the gene encoding which of the following proteins?
questions.solution: Osteogenesis imperfecta (OI) refers to a group of mainly autosomal dominant, heritable disorders of connective tissue, caused by mutations in the gene for type I collagen; this affects the skeleton, joints, ears, ligaments, teeth, sclerae, and skin. The pathogenesis of OI involves mutations of COL1A1 and COL1A2 genes, which encode the a1 and a2 chains of type I procollagen, the major structural protein of bone. Mutations in lysyl hydroxylase gene (choice C) are seen in patients with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, and mutations in the fibrillin gene (choice D) account for Marfan syndrome. Mutations in the dystrophin gene (choice B) cause Duchenne muscular dystrophy. Mutations in the fibroblast growth factor receptor gene (choice E) may result in achondroplasia.

questions.text: A female 3 day old neonate is brought to the ER after her parents noticed behavioral changes and shallow breathing. History: normal vaginal delivery, uncomplicated full-term delivery, normal antenatal care for 48 hrs in the hospital, and a normal suck and cry. On examination: generalized hypertonia and rigidity, occasional spasms, a foul-smelling brown material around the umbilical stump. Regarding the causative etiologic agent responsible for this infant’s illness, which is true?

choices.text: Toxin works by inhibiting inhibitory presynaptic neurons
Blood cultures will give gram-positive rods
Diagnosis: with laboratory confirmation of causative agent
Toxin active at peripheral neuromuscular junctions

questions.solution:
- Neonatal tetanus due to :

- infection of umbilical stump

- Circumcision

- ear-piercing

- Caused by:

- Clostridium tetanineurotoxin

- Diagnosed on clinical grounds

questions.text: A cervical Pap smear is obtained from a 30 year old patient who complains of increased vaginal discharge for 3.5 months. Two superficial squamous cells with enlarged nuclei and perinuclear vacuoles are seen. What is the most appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Human papillomavirus infection:
    • DNA virus
    • infects skin and mucosal surfaces
    • produces wart-like lesions
    • Linked to pathogenesis of cervical cancer in female reproductive tract
    • Koilocytotic atypia: sharply demarcated, large perinuclear vacuoles, with alterations in the chromatin pattern of squamous epithelial cells, filled with replicating virus particles.

questions.text: A 57 year old man complains of weakness and 6kg weight loss in the past month. An abdominal CT scan shows the possibility of metastatic cancer involving the liver and the retroperitoneum. On a CT-guided biopsy: there’s a poorly-differentiated neoplasm. Electron microscopy of the biopsy is given in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely primary site for this patient’s neoplasm?
questions.solution:
• The patient appears to be suffering from Pheochromocytoma.
  • The electron micrograph:
  • cells with granules with dense cores
  • characteristic of catecholamine-producing cells and tumors of the adrenal medulla (pheochromocytoma).

questions.text: A young woman with SLE, that is complicated by nephropathy, hemolytic anemia, and pleuritis, recently discovered that she is pregnant. She is concerned about the effect her autoimmune disease may have on her infant. Most common cardiac complication in children born to mothers with SLE is?
questions.solution:
- Congenital AV block:

- In a structurally normal heart

- Seen in children born to mothers with systemic lupus erythematosus

questions.text: A young boy dies after a severe episode of status asthmaticus. Histopathologic examination of the lung at autopsy is shown in the image. Which of the following describes the pathologic features shown in this specimen?

choices.text: Smooth muscle hyperplasia and basement membrane thickening
Interstitial fibrosis of the lung parenchyma
Intra-alveolar hemorrhage and exudates containing neutrophils

questions.solution:
• Status asthmaticus: severe asthma unresponsive to therapy.
  • HPE of lung from a patient who died in status asthmaticus: bronchus containing:
    • luminal mucous plug
    • submucosal gland hyperplasia
    • smooth muscle hyperplasia
    • basement membrane thickening
    • increased numbers of eosinophils

questions.text: Abnormalities of CF, in a newborn diagnosed with cystic fibrosis, include which of the following?

choices.text: Increased chloride secretion into the airways
Decreased water reabsorption from the airway lumen

questions.solution:
- Accumulation of mucus: common finding in children with cystic fibrosis

- (CF).

- CF:

- genetic disease

- defect in the CFTR protein (that functions as a chloride channel)

questions.text: A 52 year old man, with severe alcoholism, is admitted with acute pancreatitis. Symptoms: present for 3 days, patient still drank heavily, now has persistent vomiting. On examination: severe epigastric and right upper quadrant tenderness, decreased bowel sounds, faint blue discoloration present around the umbilicus. What is the possible significance of this?
questions.solution:
• Acute pancreatitis:
    • uncomfortable patient
    • low-grade fever
    • tachycardia
    • hypotension
    • Abdominal tenderness
    • muscle rigidity are often present to varying degrees.
    • Cullen sign: faint blue discoloration around the umbilicus due to hemoperitoneum.
    • Turner sign : blue-red-purple or green-brown discoloration of the flanks, due to tissue catabolism of hemoglobin.
  • Both these signs indicate severe necrotizing pancreatitis.

questions.text: The genotype is found to be 46,XX, after the physical examination of a newborn child whose genitalia appear to be female, but masculinized. Most likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
- Adrenogenital syndrome/ congenital virilizing hyperplasia:

- deficiency in the pathway leading to cortisol synthesis —> inability to synthesize cortisol —> high levels of ACTH and ACTH-releasing factor production from hypothalamus —> hypertrophy of fetal adrenal cortex —> excessive production of androgens by fetal adrenal —> leads to masculinization of female genitalia

questions.text: Potential indications for liver transplantation, are all of the following, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• Liver transplantation:
    • patients with alcoholic cirrhosis
    • chronic viral hepatitis
    • primary hepatocellular malignancies.

questions.text: An 18 year old female, who is 6 weeks postpartum, presents to the ER with fever, rising jaundice, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting. Examination: positive for jaundice, pain of right upper quadrant, clear chest. Normal CXR. Which of the following tests is the best approprach?

choices.text: Ultrasound of the right upper quadrant

questions.solution:
- Cholecystitis and cholelithiasis:

- unusual in children

- Associated with predisposing disorders (hemolytic anemia, pregnancy, cystic fibrosis, Crohn disease, obesity)

- Pain of the right upper quadrant

- nausea

- vomiting

- fever

- jaundice are symp- toms of acute cholecystitis.

- Diagnosis: ultrasound of gallbladder

questions.text: A patient with a history of colon cancer treated with resection and chemo, 2 years ago, is now admitted after her lab work showed BUN: 66 mg/dL, creatinine: 4.7 mg/dL. She has mild fatigue and admits to taking NSAIDS for Lower back pain. Other than stopping NSAID and avoiding nephrotoxins, which of the following should be the next step?

choices.text: Contrast CT of abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
• Urinary tract obstruction:
    • Ultrasound of the kidneys: best screening test for obstruction
    • Hydroureter and/or hydronephrosis: may show presence of obstruction.

questions.text: Surgical management of acute diverticulitis is indicated best in which of the following patients?

choices.text: 46 year-old woman with RA, treated with infliximab+prednisone
60 year-old woman with diverticulitis, in descending colon and distal stricture
None of the above patients require surgical management.

questions.solution:
• Medical management: appropriate for many patients with uncomplicated diverticular disease.
  • Surgical therapy: indicated for surgical low-risk patients with complicated disease, such as a stricture.

questions.text: A previously healthy 6 year old child suddenly complains of a headache and falls. In the ER: lethargic, left central facial weakness and left hemiparesis with conjugate ocular deviation to right. Most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
- Acute infantile hemiplegia:

- thromboembolic occlusion of the middle cerebral artery

- an acute syndrome of fever

- partial seizure

- Resulting hemiparesis

questions.text: Which one of the following statements about anorectal abscess is accurate?

choices.text: Anorectal abscess: more common in diabetic patients.
Anorectal abscess: more common in women

questions.solution:
• Anorectal abscess:
    • abnormal fluid-containing cavity in anorectal region.
    • Due to infection involving glands surrounding anorectal canal.
    • More common in males
    • peak incidence in the third to fifth decades.
    • Perianal pain with defecation and fever seen.

questions.text: An 80 year-old woman has become increasingly socially withdrawn and is brought to the OPD. The patient lives alone and is reluctant to visit or be visited by her children and family. There is also a foul odor in her apartment and on herself. Her only complaints are hemorrhoids. She has signs of depression on mental status examination. Most appropriate intervention at this time?
questions.solution:
• Procidentia:
    • more common in women than men
    • often associated with pelvic floor disorders
    • socially withdrawn
    • depression due to associated fecal incontinence
    • foul odor due to poor perianal hygiene from prolapsed rectum
    • Bailey and Love’s, 27e, p1397Examination after an enema makes prolapse apparent.

questions.text: An infant is brought to a Pediatric OPD because her wet diapers turn black when they are exposed to air. Physical examination: normal. Urine: positive for reducing substance and on testing with ferric chloride. A deficiency of which of the following would result in this disorder?
questions.solution:
- Alkaptonuria:

- autosomal recessive disorder

- deficiency of homogentisic acid oxidase.

- In infants: urine turns dark brown or black on exposure to air due to oxidation of homogentisic acid

questions.text: A middle aged woman presents to the ER with complaints of the worst headache of her life. Most appropriate initial test for diagnosis?
questions.solution: • Procedure of choice for initial diagnosis in SAH (subarachnoid hemorrhage) is a computed tomography of the head without intravenous contrast.

questions.text: A 59 year old man with facial and ocular weakness has been diagnosed with myasthenia gravis. All of the following tests are required before starting therapy EXCEPT:
questions.solution: Except for lumbar puncture, all of the other options are indicated at this time.

questions.text: A 75 year old man presents to the ER with left-sided arm weakness, rapidly improving over 4 hours. He has a past history of: hypertension, dyslipidemia, and coronary artery disease with a double coronary angioplasty. He is on: aspirin: 80 mg daily, metoprolol: 100 mg bid, benazepril: 20 mg daily, rosuvastatin: 10 mg daily, and clopidogrel:75 mg daily. On evaluation: 75% occlusion of the right internal carotid artery. What information is required by the patient to make a decision on whether he should undergo a carotid endarterectomy?

choices.text: Risk of stroke in next 90 days
Risk of stroke in next year

questions.solution:
• The choice to undergo a carotid endarterectomy depends on:
  • degree of stenosis
  • If patient is symptomatic or not
  • In individuals with asymptomatic carotid artery stenosis: risk of stroke is ~2% per year
  • In symptomatic patient: the annual risk of stroke is ~13%

questions.text: A 45 year-old man is examined in the ER for chest pain that developed after swallowing a piece of meat. He complains of intermittent episodes of meat getting stuck in his lower chest in the past 3 years and denies food regurgitation or heartburn. He is also able to swallow liquids without difficulty. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Intermittent solid food dysphagia: classic symptom in Schatzki ring
  • Schatzki ring: distal esophageal ring occurs at squamocolumnar mucosal junction
  • Origin: unclear
  • In lumen is less than 13 mm: dysphagia
  • Schatzki rings often cause “steakhouse syndrome”: meat getting stuck in the ring. The rings are typically easily treated with dilation.

questions.text: Potential causes of appendix obstruction and appendicitis include all of the following, EXCEPT:
questions.solution: Cholelithiasis is a common cause of acute pancreatitis.

questions.text: A 42 year old man presented in August with abdominal pain for two days, diffuse myalgias, and severe headache. He said that he spent a day 2 weeks ago planting a garden and a week ago he ate raw oysters. On examination: blanchable macules on wrists and ankles. A provisional diagnosis is made, and his disease has a mortality rate of 40% if not treated. What is the responsible pathogen?
questions.solution:
- Rocky Mountain spotted fever (RMSF):

- Caused by Rickettsia rickettsii

- Spread by tick vector

- patient possibly exposed to tick bite in the garden

- RMSF rash:

- begins on wrists and ankles

- spreads centripetally

- appears on palms and soles later

- Lesions —> blanchable macules to petechiae.

- Requires prompt treatment: mortality of untreated disease = 40%.

questions.text: Infectious organism most likely to cause relative bradycardia during a febrile event is which one of the following?
questions.solution:
- Intracellular Gram-negative bacteria, tick-borne organisms, some viruses:

- cause infections associated with relative bradycardia (Faget sign)

- patients have a lower heart rate than expected for a given body temperature

questions.text: Chronic dialysis: associated with increased risk of healthcare-associated pneumonia, is caused by which one of the following?
questions.solution:
- Healthcare-associated pneumonia (HCAP):

- Residence in a nursing home or hospitalizations for >2 days in 3 months

- current hospitalizations > 48 hours

- Associated with:

- methicillin-resistant S aureus

- Paeruginosa

- Acinetobacter species

- multidrug-resistantEnterobacteriaceae

questions.text: Which of the following patients should not be treated for C difficile infection?

choices.text: 50 year old patient with diarrhea for 2 weeks, pseudomembranes found on colonoscopy
62 year old woman with fever, leukocytosis, adynamic ileus, and a positive stool PCR for C difficile
69 year old woman on antibiotic course, admitted to ICU for pain abdomen
77 year old woman on amoxicillin for upper respiratory tract infection yesterday, now has two loose bowel movements/ day/ 3 days; afebrile, WBC: 8700

questions.solution:
- C difficile infection:

- diarrhea with >3 stools per day for ≥2 days

- toxin A or B demonstrated in stool, PCR or culture

- presence of toxin-producing C difficile in the stool

- identifying pseudomembranes in colon on endoscopy

- PCR: more sensitive than toxin assays and at least as specific

questions.text: Diagnostic features characterizing bacterial vaginosis is which one of the following?

choices.text: Vaginal fluid pH <4.5, clue cells, profuse mixed microbiota on microscopic exam
Vaginal fluid pH >4.5, clue cells, profuse mixed microbiota on microscopic exam
Vaginal fluid pH ≥5.0, motile trichomonads on microscopic exam, and fishy odor
Vaginal fluid pH <4.5, lactobacilli on microscopic exam, and scant clear secretions

questions.solution:
- Bacterial vaginosis:

- associated with Gardnerella vaginalis, anaerobic bacteria

- Maladorous discharge: white or gray.

- No external irritation

- pH of vaginal fluid is >4.5

- fishy odor present with 10% KOH

- microscopy: clue cells, leukocytes, mixed microbiota

questions.text: The following are all predisposing conditions that raise the risk of acute bacterial meningitis, caused by S pneumoniae EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
- S pneumoniae:

- MCC of meningitis in adults >20 years of age,

- Pneumococcal pneumonia increases risk of pneumococcal meningitis

- Other risk factors:

- coexisting acute or chronic pneumococcal sinusitis

- otitis media

- alcoholism

- diabetes

- splenectomy

- hypogammaglobulinemia

- complement deficiency

- head trauma

- basilar skull fracture CSF rhinorrhea

questions.text: On leaving the room of which one of the following patients would the use of an alcohol-based hand rub be inadequate?

choices.text: 76 year old senior citizen with C. difficile infection and antibiotic use
21 year old renal transplant recipient with varicella pneumonia
44 year old man with MRSA furunculitis
37 year old woman with advanced HIV and cavitary pulmonary TB

questions.solution:
- Nosocomial infections:

- have reservoirs and sources

- cross-contamination (i.e., indirect spread of organisms from one patient to next) occurs

- alcohol-based hand rubs recommended for all healthcare workers

- Hand rubs not recommended when hands are visibly soiled or after the care of a patient with C difficile infection (spores may not be killed by alcohol, require thorough hand washing with soap and water)

questions.text: In the first 2 weeks after solid organ transplantation, the most common family of infection is?
questions.solution:
- Post-organ transplant patients are maximally at risk of infections typical for hospitalized patients (in the first two weeks), including: - wound infections

- UTI

- pneumonia

- C difficile infection

- line-associated infection

questions.text: A 42 year old woman, with AML, undergoes allogeneic stem cell transplantation. She is admitted to the hospital, two weeks later, with temperature: 102.1°F, pulse: 118 bpm, BP: 110/88 mmHg, SpO2: 88% on room air. Leukogram shows neutropenia. CXR: pulmonary infiltrates, CT scan: diffuse nodules with halo sign. The most likely to be diagnostic of her disease is?
questions.solution:
- In first week after hematopoietic stem cell transplantation—> highest risk of infection —> aerobic nosocomially acquired bacteria. - After 7 days —> risk of fungal infection increases

- Px with symptoms of respiratory illness, neutropenia, CT nodular findings with halo sign: possible fungal (Aspergillus) infection.

- Serum galactomannan antigen test —> detects galactomannan (major component of Aspergillus cell wall) —> this compound suggests invasion and growth.

questions.text: Which of the followin regarding the bacterium, S aureus, is true?

choices.text: anterior nares,oropharynx: most common sites of colonization
S aureus is always a pathogen, never a commensal

questions.solution:
- S aureus: a commensal AND an opportunistic pathogen.

- The anterior nares + oropharynx: frequent sites of human colonization; sometimes even the skin (especially damaged), vagina, axilla, perineum

- Colonization of different body sites —> allow transfer from one person to another, by contact

questions.text: A 21 year old woman with no past medical history, presents with 12 hours of dyspnea after a long car ride. She takes only an oral contraceptive. Physical examination: afebrile, RR: 22 breaths/min, BP: 120/80 mmHg, HR: 110 bpm, SpO2: 92% on room air. Normal CBC and CXR. What is the indicated management strategy?

choices.text: Check D-dimer —> normal —> discharge with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory therapy
Check D-dimer —> normal —> lower extremity ultrasound
Check D-dimer —> abnormal —> treat for DVT/ PE
Get contrast multislice CT of chest

questions.solution:
• This patient has a clinical probability score of 4.5 (resting tachycardia and no alternative diagnosis)
  • Hence, there is no indication to check D-dimer.
  • Patient should proceed directly to multislice CT of the chest.

Low clinical likelihood of DVT if point score is ) or less; moderate likelihood if score is 1 to 2; high likelihood if score is 3 or greater

Clinical Variable DVT Score
Active cancer 1
Paralysis, paresis, or recent cast 1
Bedridden for >3 days; major surgery <12 weeks 1
Tenderness along distribution of deep veins 1
Entire leg swelling 1
Unilateral calf swelling>3 cm 1
Pitting edema 1
Collateral superficial nonvaricose veins 1
Alternative diagnosis at least as likely as DVT -2
High clinical likelihood of PE is point
Clinical Variable PE Score
Signs and Symptoms of DVT 3.0
Alternative diagnosis less likely than PE 3.0
Heart rate >100/min 1.5
Immobilization >3 days; surgery within 4 weeks 1.5
Prior PE or DVT 1.5
Hemoptysis 1.0
Cancer 1.0

questions.text: A 54 year-old man is examined for sudden-onset cough, dyspnea and yellow sputum production. He has a history of systemic hypertension and is on amlodipine. CXR: right upper lobe alveolar infiltrate; BUN: 54 mg/dL, creatinine: 2.9 mg/dL, calcium: 12.2 mg/dL, albumin of 3.2 g/dL. Sputum culture: Streptococcus pneumoniae. Which of the following tests will confirm the diagnosis of an underlying condition which predisposes him to pneumococcal pneumonia?
questions.solution:
• Multiple myeloma:
  • These patients have functional hypogammaglobulinemia.
  • decreased production of normal Abs
  • increased destruction of normal antibodies
  • Predisposition of patients to infections (pneumococcus, S aureus)
  • Bone marrow biopsy: confirms clonal plasma cells.

questions.text: Which of the following results is the most powerful predictor of survival in patients with multiple myeloma?
questions.solution:
• Serum β2-microglobulin:
    • Patients with β2-microglobulin levels <0.004 g/L: median survival of 43 months
    • Patient with levels >0.004 g/L: survival of only 12 months.

questions.text: An 18 year old reports 1 week of pain and has developed more severe pain on the right side of her lower abdomen over one day, and fever; pain in right upper abdomen worsened by deep breathing. She is sexually active with multiple partners. Examination: fever, normal breath sounds, mild tachycardia, and a tender right upper quadrant without rebound. Pelvic exam: normal cervical appearance, cervical motion tenderness, adnexal tenderness. A urine pregnancy test: negative; leukocytosis on CBC. Which of the following is true about her right upper quadrant tenderness, specifically?

choices.text: CT chest to confirm septic pulmonary emboli
Laparoscopic examination to show inflammation of liver capsule.
Plasma PCR: for acute hepatitis C virus

questions.solution:
• Right upper quadrant tenderness + classic findings of pelvic inflammatory disease = Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome, or perihepatitis.
  • Occurs due to inflammation of the liver capsule by either N gonorrhoeae or C trachomatis infection

questions.text: A 67 year old man, with a history of alcohol abuse, presents with several weeks of fever, night sweats, and production of sputum. Examination: low-grade temperature, weight loss: 7.5kg, foul breath. Blood work is unremarkable. Interferon-γ release assay is negative. CXR shown below. Which of the following is an appropriate initial therapy?

choices.text: Bronchoscopy with biopsy of cavity to diagnose lung cancer

questions.solution:
• Lung infection (lung abscess):
  • CXR: large cavity with air-fluid level in right lower lobe,
  • Often associated with aspiration of oral anaerobic bacteria (who produce beta-lactamases) that are normally found in teeth crevices
  • Meropenem, β-lactam/β-lactamase inhibitor combinations, clindamycin, and metronidazole are given for initial treatment of the lung abscess.

questions.text: An initial primary survey of the chest is done to quickly and accurately identify all of the following causes of cardiorespiratory compromise, except
questions.solution:
• Thoracic injuries (immediate threat to life) include:
    • flail chest
    • tension pneumothorax
    • open pneumothorax
    • massive haemothorax
    • cardiac tamponade

questions.text: Which one of the following is NOT a recognized complication of severe burn injury?
questions.solution: Pancreatitis: not caused by burn injuries, but may be associated with hypothermia.

questions.text: A 30 year-old man gets evaluated for coronary risk factors. He is healthy and has a history of no tobacco use, normal blood pressure, and no diabetes. However, he has a family history of high cholesterol on his maternal side. Tendon xanthomas are seen on physical examination. LDL: 388 mg/dL on fasting cholesterol. Most likely genetic disorder affecting this individual is?
questions.solution:
- Familial hypercholesterolemia (aka Autosomal dominant hypercholesterolemia Type 1)

- most common inherited cause hypercholesterolemia

- caused by loss-of-function mutations in the gene encoding the low-density lipoprotein receptor

- Heterozygous FH (single mutation): decrease of LDL receptors in the liver → decrease in clearance of LDL from the circulation. Plasma levels of LDL: 200–400 mg/dL.

- Homozygous FH (two mutations): LDL receptors reduced or absent. LDL cholesterol levels: 400 to >1000 mg/dL. Cutaneous xanthomas seen in childhood, early CVS disorders in late childhood or young adulthood

questions.text: A man, who is unresponsive after being found on a winter night on a park bench, is brought to the ER. No external signs of injury. Esophageal temperature probe: core body temperature is 34 °C. Management option not routinely indicated in this case?
questions.solution:
• Hypothermia:
    • mild (35–32°C)
    • moderate (32–30°C)
    • severe (less than 30°C)
  • Clinical manifestations:
    • decreased consciousness
    • decreased respiratory rate
    • decreased heart rate
    • Decreased Cardiac output
    • cardiac arrhythmia
  • ‘Active core rewarming methods’: reserved for severe hypothermia or in high-risk patients, and include:
    • warmed peritoneal lavage
    • warmed pleural lavage
    • warmed bladder irrigation
    • arterio-venousrewarming
    • cardiopulmonary bypass.

questions.text: Not an independent indication for laparotomy following trauma is which one of the following?
questions.solution:
• Explorative laparotomy is not indicated in stab wounds as:
  • 33% of anterior abdominal stab wounds fail to penetrate the peritoneum
  • Only 30% of stabbing injuries cause visceral injuries.

questions.text: Complication of lymphoedema of the arm more likely to occur post resection of a breast tumour and axillary clearance in which of the following scenarios?

choices.text: Mastectomy + axillary clearance + postoperative radiotherapy to the chest wall
Mastectomy + axillary clearance + postoperative radiotherapy to the axilla

questions.solution:
• Lymphoedema of the arm occurs after:
    • combination of surgical axillary clearance
    • postoperative radiotherapy to the axilla.

questions.text: In patients with noted intravascular hemolysis, which one of the following statements about hyperbilirubinemia is true?
questions.solution:
- Increased destruction of erythrocytes —> increased bilirubin turnover —> unconjugatedhyperbilirubinemia

- This hyperbilirubinemia: modest, with normal liver function.

- Higher values: concomitant hepatic dysfunction

questions.text: Identify the program symbol shown in below image ?
Which of the following proteolytic enzymes is activated by acid hydrolysis of the proenzyme form?
questions.solution:
- Pepsin: secreted in proenzyme form in stomach. (Not activated by protease hydrolysis)

- Spontaneous acid hydrolysis at < pH 2 —> converts pepsinogen to pepsin

questions.text: Identify the organization showen in below image ?

A 5 year old girl has a speech delay and is also found to have a large peak in blood amino acid measurement. The amino acid that is causing this large peak migrates towards the anode —> which shows a positively charged side group along with carbonyl and amino groups. Which combination of amino acid to medical procedure is the most important in this case?
questions.solution:
- All α-amino groups and α-carboxyl groups: utilized in peptide bonds (except terminal amino acids).

- Side chains of amino acids: ionizable in proteins.

- Easily ionizable side chained amino acids:

- Lysine

- arginine

- histidine (basic side chains, gives a positive charge at neutral pH with migration toward negative anode)

- aspartate

- glutamate

- tyrosine

- cysteine

- Hearing test: first investigation for speech delay.

- Hearing loss: mcc of speech problems

questions.text: Identify the person given in below image ?
Which one of the following would result in an increased affinity of hemoglobin for O2?

choices.text: Initial O2 binding to any of the four sites on deoxyhemoglobin molecule

questions.solution:
- O2 molecule addition to deoxyhemoglobin: needs breakage of salt links (e.g. by 2,3-BPG)

- Each subsequent O2 molecule —> requires fewer salt link breakage

- Hence, initial O2 binding —> increased affinity for subsequent O2 binding

questions.text: Which one of the following is done by a noncompetitive inhibitor of an enzyme?
questions.solution:
- Noncompetitive inhibitors: NOT structural analogs of the substrate

- They bind to enzymes in locations remote from the active site. Hence, degree of inhibition — based only upon concentration of inhibitor.

- Increasing substrate concentrations do not compete with or change the inhibition.

- So in noncompetitive inhibition: Vmax decreases, Km remains the same. And is irreversible

questions.text: Fructose was previously recommended for patients with diabetes mellitus. Which of the following would be an appropriate explanation for this?

choices.text: Fructose: has specific kinase in liver that allows bypass of phosphofructokinase (PFK)
Fructose: phosphorylated and cleaved to triose phosphates, these can’t be used for gluconeogenesis

questions.solution:
- Fructose has a special metabolism pathway in liver, kidney, and small intestine.

- Syrups, beverages, or diabetic substitutes (high in fructose-glucose) lead to higher concentrations of fructose in the portal vein.

- Fructose — catabolized more rapidly than glucose by specific fructokinase — bypassing hexokinase that is regulated by fasting and insulin

questions.text: The following drugs all interfere with testicular function EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• Ketoconazole: inhibits testosterone synthesis. Spironolactone: blockade of androgen action, may also cause gynecomastia.
  • Glucocorticoids: hypogonadism through inhibition of hypothalamic-pituitary function.

questions.text: A 74 year woman is hospitalized for a right hip fracture. She is transferred to rehabilitation after initial surgical treatment. Her 25-hydroxyvitamin D levels are at 18.4 ng/L. What is the recommended treatment in this patient?

choices.text: Vitamin D3 - 800 U daily with calcium carbonate - 1500 mg daily
Vitamin D3 - 2000 U daily with calcium carbonate - 1500 mg daily

questions.solution:
• Levels less than 20 ng/L (<50 nmol/L) need to be repleted.
  • Recommended daily intake (with no vitamin D deficiency) is 800 IU of vitamin D, daily.
  • In hypovitaminosis, vitamin D3 at 2000 IU daily along with calcium supplementation is recommended.

questions.text: Regulation of lipogenesis takes place due to which one of the following enzymes most importantly?
questions.solution:
- Acetyl-CoA carboxylase: catalyzes first step of lipogenesis (where acetyl-CoA is linked to malonyl-CoA)

- Activated by citrate

- Does not readily cross the mitochondrial membrane

- Citrate translocates to cytosol —> cleaved to acetyl-CoA and oxaloacetate (by ATP-citrate lyase).

- Citrate increases in fed state, which indicates an abundant supply of acetyl-CoA for lipogenesis

questions.text: Which of the following medications would you prescribe to reduce attacks and prevent the development of systemic amyloidosis in a 17 year old who is diagnosed with familial Mediterranean fever?
questions.solution: Rx of FMF: daily oral colchicine, to decrease the frequency and intensity of attacks and prevent development of amyloidosis in compliant patients.

questions.text: All of the following agents to have disease-modifying antirheumatic drug efficacy in patients with rheumatoid arthritis EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• Methotrexate: DMARD of choice in early RA.
  • Rituximab (anti-CD20 antibody): used for refractory RA in combination with methotrexate.
  • Naproxen is an NSAID that is not considered a DMARD.

questions.text: The correct sequence in gene repair mechanisms in non-mutated repair processes is which one of the following?

choices.text: Recognition, nicking, excision, replacement, and sealing
Nicking, recognition, excision, sealing, and replacement
Nicking, sealing, recognition, excision, and replacement
Nicking, excision, replacement, sealing, and recognition

questions.solution:
- Common sequence of events in normal gene repair:

  1. Single or multiple base abnormality survey and detection by a specific protein or proteins.
  2. DNA: nicked on one side of damaged DNA.
  3. Specific enzyme excises the damaged portion
  4. Damaged portion of the strand replacement by resynthesis catalyzed by DNA polymerase I.
  5. Ligase seals the final gap

questions.text: A man, who has recently been diagnosed with systemic hypertension, is prescribed lisinopril as an initial monotherapy. His right hand is swollen, mildly itching, and tingling with eventual lip swelling and difficulty in breathing after only three days of taking Lisinopril. Accurate description of this condition is?

choices.text: Symptoms are due to direct activation of mast cells by lisinopril
Symptoms due to impaired bradykinin degradation by lisinopril
Peripheral blood analysis: deficiency of C1 inhibitor

questions.solution:
• Angioedema:
    • rapid onset of facial swelling (including lips)
    • preceding limb symptoms.
  • ACE inhibitor use (lisinopril) is associated with increased levels of bradykinin.

questions.text: In a 56 year old man with hemochromatosis resulting in cirrhosis and portal hypertension, there is presentation with altered mental status, chronic ascites, one previous esophageal bleed. He is on propranolol. Afebrile, normal vital signs. Lab examination: Hb 10.1, creatinine 1.4, BUN 45. Paracentesis reveals clear fluid with 900 WBC. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
• Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP):
    • spontaneous infection of the ascitic fluid
    • without intra-abdominal source
    • Most common organisms: Ecoli, Streptococcus viridans, Staphylococcus aureus
    • Treatment: with second-generation cephalosporin, with cefotaxime.

questions.text: One of the following drugs has a direct toxic effect on hepatocytes, choose the right option?
questions.solution:
• In therapeutic doses: acetaminophen doesn’t cause liver injury.
  • At higher doses, N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone imine (NAPQI) (acetaminophen metabolite)
    • overwhelms glutathione stores of liver (which convert NAPQI to nontoxic metabolite)
    • leads to hepatocyte necrosis.

questions.text: A 39 year old woman with AIDS, has a CD4 count of 35/ μL and presents with odynophagia and progressive dysphagia, daily fevers and 10kg weight loss. BMI - 16, weight - 42kg, temperature - 100.9°F. On esophagogastroduodenoscopy, non- vesicular serpiginous ulcers are seen in the distal esophagus. What is the treatment for this patient’s esophagitis?
questions.solution:
• Esophagitis, in patients with HIV:
    • Caused by herpes simplex virus
    • cytomegalovirus
    • varicella-zoster virus
    • Candida
    • HIV itself.
  • On biopsy: intranuclear and intracytoplasmic inclusions with enlarged nuclei in large fibroblasts + endothelial cells.
  • I/v ganciclovir: treatment of choice.

questions.text: In a 32 year-old man with end-stage cystic fibrosis, who undergoes lung transplantation, there is progressive decline in his kidney function. Which one of the following medications is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
• CKD: common finding after lung transplantation.
  • Cyclosporine, tacrolimus: calcineurin inhibitors used in immunosuppressive regimens after lung transplantation.

questions.text: Quick activation or deactivation by phosphorylation of specific amino acid residues is catalyzed by which one of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
- Highly regulated protein kinases: can result in activation or deactivation of key regulatory proteins —> by covalent modification of specific hydroxyl residues by phosphorylation of:

- serine

- threonine

- tyrosine

questions.text: One of the following medications has been shown to reduce mortality in patients of heart failure with decreased ejection fraction?
questions.solution: β-Blockers: benefit in HFrEF seen with metoprolol succinate, bisoprolol, and carvedilol.

questions.text: Which one of the following, about nesiritide, is accurate in patients with acute decompensated heart failure, who require invasive hemodynamic monitoring?

choices.text: No significant effect on blood pressure.
Improvement in renal perfusion in acute decompensated heart failure.
Reduces pulmonary capillary wedge more quickly than IV nitrates

questions.solution:
• Nesiritide:
    • recombinant form of human BNP
    • Initially fixed dose for therapy of acute decompensated heart failure
    • Shows more rapid and greater reduction in pulmonary capillary wedge pressure than with i/v nitrates.

questions.text: All of the following medications, that are used in primary management of STEMI, are accurately matched to their respective mechanism of effect EXCEPT

choices.text: β-Adrenergic antagonists – myocardial oxygen consumption reduction

questions.solution:
• Nitroglycerin:
    • decreases pre load
    • Some direct nitric oxide induction of coronary vasodilation
    • Minimal to no effect on systemic after load.

questions.text: Which of the following structures would accomplish detection of angular acceleration?

choices.text: Hair cells of organ of Corti

questions.solution:
• Semicircular canals
    • extend from utricle
    • contain cristaeampullares
    • detect angular acceleration

questions.text: Which one of the following is directly involved in sound transduction?

choices.text: Neurotransmitter release onto afferent endings of CN VIII
Shearing motion of tympanic membrane against stereocilia
Tectorial membrane movement causing in hair cell depolarization
Vibration at round window via stapes

questions.solution:
• Movement of the tectorial membrane —> hair cell depolarization —> release of neurotransmitter onto afferent endings of auditory cranial nerve —> initiation of an action potential
  • Sound waves: directed toward tympanic membrane by pinna and external auditory canal of external ear.
  • Vibration of tympanic membrane: transmitted to oval window by ossicles of middle ear.

questions.text: A man presents with severe abdominal distention and pain. He has a palpable bladder. After catheterization, 1.7 L of urine passes. He hasn’t passed urine for 2 days. BUN: 89 mg/dL, creatinine: 6.5 mg/dL. He eventually passes 6.2 L of urine on the third and fourth days of hospital admission. What is the most likely explanation for his increased urine output?
questions.solution:
• Postobstructive diuresis:
    • release of obstruction
    • increase in GFR over days
    • Reduced tubule pressure
    • resulting in increased urine output.

questions.text: A 13 year old boy is brought to the ER due to nasal fullness and bleeding. On inspection: enlarged cervical lymph nodes. Biopsy of node: nasopharyngeal carcinoma. Best management strategy for this patient?
questions.solution:
• Chemoradiation:
    • standard therapy for nasopharyngeal carcinoma
    • Intracavitary radiation + external beam radiation therapy used
  • Surgical resection: not typically used, but can be considered for local recurrences.
  • Risk factors for nasopharyngeal carcinoma:
    • environment
    • ethnicity
    • tobacco
    • strong association with Epstein-Barr virus infections,

questions.text: A 67 year old man complains of lightning-like pains to his thighs for the past few minutes. There is impaired proprioception and vibratory sense in his feet. Patient with wide-based, ataxic gait, positive Romberg sign. His wife was treated for syphilis 32 years ago, but he was never tested or treated for syphilis. Ocular finding most consistent with neurosyphilis is?

choices.text: Pupils reactive to accommodation but not light
Pupils reactive to light but not accommodation
Pupils reactive to both light and accommodation
Pupils nonreactive to both light or accommodation

questions.solution:
- Syphilitic involvement of the CNS:

- Occurs in both early or late syphilis

- Can be:

- asymptomaticneurosyphilis

- meningeal syphilis

- meningovascular syphilis

- general paresis

- tabes dorsalis.

- Primary ocular finding:

- Argyll Robertson pupil

- Pupils fail to react to light

- accommodation is preserved.

- Both pupils usually involved.

- pupils typically small

- They do not dilate fully in dim light

- pupils constrict to near vision

- Pupils dilate to far vision

questions.text: The outward recoil of the chest wall equals to the inward elastic recoil of the lung at which of the following capacities?
questions.solution:
• Functional residual capacity:
    • volume of air that remains in the lung after normal tidal respiration
    • Point at which outward recoil of the chest wall is in equilibrium with inward elastic recoil of the lungs
    • consists of: expiratory reserve volume and residual volume.

questions.text: Which one of the following will result in a faster rate of absorption of alcohol from gut into blood?

choices.text: Concurrent intake of a high-protein meal
Concentration of alcohol of more than 20% by volume
Concurrent intake of a high-fat meal

questions.solution: • Factor that increases absorption of alcohol - rapid gastric emptying, which is induced by concurrent consumption of carbonated beverages.

questions.text: An old man, who is a smoker, presents with a 4 month history of enlarged lymph node in his left neck. He denies fevers, night sweats, fatigue, or cough. On physical examination: 1.5-cm hard, fixed mass below angle of mandible in left neck. Most likely cause of an enlarged lymph node in the neck, is?
questions.solution:
• Lymphadenopathy in an adult —> metastatic squamous cell cancer (SCC).
  • Metastatic SCC:
    • originates from nasopharynx, oropharynx, hypopharynx.
    • Lymphadenopathy
    • persistent lateral neck masses in adults, which may represent:
      • neuromas
      • neurofibromas
      • carotid body tumors
      • branchial cleft cysts
      • lipomas
      • sebaceous cysts
      • parathyroid cysts
      • primary soft tissue tumor.

questions.text: The following are all true regarding Iridoschisis, except:

choices.text: Due to a split between iris stroma and pigment epithelium
associated with glaucoma in 50% of cases

questions.solution:
- Iridoschisis:

- degenerative disorder involving lower quadrant of iris near pupil.

- Uncommon condition, usually affects elderly.

- Splitting of the iris: between anterior and posterior stroma.

- Idiopathic in most cases

- Associated with glaucoma in 50% of cases

questions.text: A woman, who underwent total thyroidectomy for multinodular goiter 7 months ago, presents with persistent hoarseness. Nerve most likely injured during her operation is which one of the following?
questions.solution:
• Recurrent laryngeal nerve damage:
    • Occurs due to previous surgery (thyroidectomy, malignancy)
    • Unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury:
      • Hoarseness
      • voice changes
      • weak cough
      • difficulty swallowing.

questions.text: When the plasma glucose falls below 80–85 mg/dL, which one of the following physiologic changes is the first to occur?
questions.solution:
• Maintenance of euglycemia:
  1. decrease in insulin secretion
  2. Increase in hepatic glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis.
  3. decreased peripheral glucose utilization.
  4. Glucagon secretion
  5. Further stimulation of hepatic gluconeogenesis.
  6. Secretion of Epinephrine, Cortisol and growth hormone (after 4 hours of hypoglycemia).

questions.text: An HIV-positive patient presents to the ER with deep boring ear pain, red inflamed ear canal and pinna. All of the following statements are true, except:

choices.text: Treated conservatively with rest and topical hygiene

questions.solution: This is a serious condition, and it requires local debridement and intravenous antibiotics

questions.text: A 20 year old man, with a 1-day history of discomfort and a ‘leaky’ left eye, presents to the OPD. His brother also had similar symptoms. His vision is entirely unchanged and there is no history of previous trauma. Physical examination: a red eye with uniform engorgement of all conjunctival blood vessels. What is the likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
- Conjunctivitis:

- inflammation of conjunctiva

- most common causes of discomfort and red eye

- typically bilateral

- may be viral (self-limiting) or bacterial.

- Therapy: chloramphenicol eye drops to the affected eye

questions.text: Which one of the following options is true as a differential diagnosis for a patient presenting with rhinitis?
questions.solution:
• Nasal polyps can cause nasal discharge.
  • The viruses that are responsible for the common cold commonly cause rhinitis

questions.text: Normal glucose tolerance is?

choices.text: Fasting plasma glucose <126 mg/dL following an oral glucose challenge
Fasting plasma glucose <100 mg/dL, hemoglobin A1C <5.6%

questions.solution:
• Glucose tolerance:
    • three categories:
      1. normal glucose tolerance (fasting plasma glucose <100 mg/dL, plasma glucose <140 mg/dL after an oral glucose challenge, and hemoglobin A1C <5.6%)
      2. impaired glucose homeostasis (fasting plasma glucose of 100–125 mmol/dL or a plasma glucose of 140–199 following an oral glucose tolerance test or hemoglobin A1C of 5.7%–6.4%)
      3. diabetes mellitus (fasting plasma glucose >126 mg/dL, glucose of 200 mg/dL after an oral glucose tolerance test, or hemoglobin A1C ≥6.5%

questions.text: In a patient who requires complete resection of the pituitary gland after the diagnosis of a pituitary tumor, which of the following listed functions of adrenal gland will be preserved immediately postoperatively?

choices.text: Morning peak of plasma cortisol level
Sodium retention in response to hypovolemia

questions.solution:
• 3 major functions of adrenal gland:
    1. glucocorticoid synthesis (controlled by the pituitary secretion of ACTH)
    2. aldosterone synthesis (primary stimulus for RAAS, independent of the pituitary)
    3. androgen precursor synthesis.
  • Hence, morning cortisol secretion and release of cortisol in response to stress- regulated by the pituitary gland
  • Regulation of sodium retention + potassium excretion by aldosterone: independent of pituitary, is preserved in this patient.

questions.text: All of the following are true about the management of chronic/primary open angle glaucoma, except:
questions.solution:
- Primary/chronic open angle glaucoma:

- Commonest form of glaucoma

- gradual resistance to the outflow of aqueous humour through trabecular network.

- Increased risk due to advancing age, diabetes, myopia.

- Symptoms may be absent

- Central visual fields: spared until late in the disease.

- Treated with:

- β-blockers (timolol) to reduce secretion of aqueous

- carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (acetazolamide) to reduce aqueous secretion

- pilocarpine to constrict pupil and increase aqueous outflow

- laser trabeculoplasty – may be required

questions.text: Voice abusers are at risk of developing all of the following conditions, except:
questions.solution:
• Voice abuse: as strenuous exertion of voice.
  • Seen in singing, teaching and public speaking.
  • Reinke’s oedema:
    • AKA bilateral diffuse polyposis
    • swelling in lamina propria between vocal cord ligament and surface epithelium (Reinke’s space)
    • responds well to conservative measures, like smoking cessation and resting voice.
  • Vocal nodules:
    • small nodules that occur on middle third of vocal cord
    • prevent complete adduction of cords
    • Hence result in a hoarse voice.
  • Capillary ectasia:
    • the formation of dilated vessels on vocal cords.
    • Treated by resting voice, voice therapy.
  • Tonsillitis:
    • Infection of the tonsils
    • Not associated with voice abuse.

questions.text: Which one of the mechanisms enlisted below of autoimmunity is mainly responsible for the development of rheumatic fever?
questions.solution:
• Molecular mimicry in rheumatic fever:
  • antibodies to M protein of streptococci cross-react with myosin, laminin, and other matrix proteins, and also with neuronal antigens —> Deposition of such autoantibodies in heart —> initiation of inflammatory response —> if penetration into brain —> results in Sydenham chorea.

questions.text: Which one of the following is a major source of heat loss in normal human adults?
questions.solution:
• Evaporation of skin moisture:
    • most effective mechanism of heat loss
    • becomes ineffective with increasing humidity.
  • The skin surface is the radiator and principal location of heat loss:
    • As skin blood flow can increase over 25–30 times over basal rate, which combines with vasodilation to radiate heat.

questions.text: Which property of SA nodal cells allows it to act as the primary pacemaker of the heart?

choices.text: It’s location near superior lateral area of right atrium
The isolated cells with ability to depolarize spontaneously

questions.solution: • SA node has the “steepest” phase 4 slope —> depolarizes more rapidly than any other potential pacemaker cells.

questions.text: An 83 year old man presents to the ER with a sudden loss of central aspects of his visual fields. On examination: bilateral visual acuity is mildly reduced. Central lines on an Amsler chart: distorted. Peripheral fields: normal. Fundoscopy: multiple retinal infiltrates, the macula is normal in size and shape. Most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
- Macular degeneration of old age:

- One of the Leading causes of blindness

- Loss of central vision

- Yellow retinal deposits or drusen

- macula may look normal.

questions.text: Mean QRS vectors in the frontal electrocardiographic plane are matched appropriately to their designation in which one of the following?
Which of the following is the most appropriate statement about chemical ocular injury?

choices.text: The severity of injury is unrelated to the substance

questions.solution:
- Alkaline chemicals:

- high pH —> penetrate surface of eye —> cause severe injury to external structures (cornea) and internal structures (lens)

- More damage occurs with higher pH chemicals than with acids.

questions.text:
A patient with a history of ischaemic heart disease and A-Fib presents to the ER with abdominal pain. CT shows features of ischemic bowel. The patient's blood gases are as follows:

pH = 7.27
paO2 = 11
paCO2 = 2.9
HCO3 = 17
Base excess = –9

Which of the following describes the patient's acid–base status accurately?

choices.text: Metabolic acidosis with adequate respiratory compensation
Metabolic acidosis with inadequate respiratory compensation

questions.solution:
• Ischemic bowel:
  • common cause of metabolic acidosis.
  • But paCO2 level is low: respiratory compensation
  • Still low pH: this respiratory compensation is inadequate.

questions.text: A 44 year old man presents with pain in his left eye. He was recently doing some repair work in the house and felt ‘some material entering his eye’. He does not wear contact lenses and his eye has been extremely watery. He is unable to open it properly. The following statements regarding assessment are accurate, except

choices.text: Eyelid laceration is sutured in the ER

questions.solution:
- Lacerations to the eyelids need specialist attention, if:

  • lid margins are torn
  • Lacrimal ducts are damaged
  • foreign body or penetrating eyelid injur

questions.text: The renal ability to excrete concentrated urine will rise if:

choices.text: Permeability of the collecting duct to H2O increases
Rate of flow of filtrate through the loop of Henle rises
Na-K pump activity in loop of Henle decreases

questions.solution:
• Countercurrent multiplier: helps the kidney to excrete concentrated urine —> after increasing the tonicity of medullary interstitium.
  • Anything to reduce the ability of countercurrent multiplier (like increasing flow of fluid through loop of Henle) —> decreases the ability of the kidney to excrete a concentrated urine.

questions.text: A type of injury, that is usually made with a blunt object, that can be seen on physical examination and is dated by the color change over time is most likely to be described by which one of the following terms?
In young children, what is the common presentation of retinoblastoma, a malignant tumour of the retina?
questions.solution:
- Retinoblastoma:

- often calcified

- Usually present with the appearance of a white pupil reflex

- May present with a squint

- fundus examination required

questions.text: In a lady who was shot by a revolver at a distance of 2m, the inlet would be?
questions.solution:
• Entrance wounds: point where the bullet enters the biological target
  • General features:
    • Abrasion ring: reddish brown abrasion on skin surrounding the gunshot wound of entrance
    • Greasy rim/ bullet wipe: dirt collar due to the lubricant carried on the bullet
    • Inverted edges: due to the bullet movement inside the body
    • Smaller than bullet caliber (usually): due to the elastic recoil of the affected tissues

questions.text: All of the following are features of barbiturate poisoning except:
questions.solution:
• Neurologic manifestations:
    • Lethargy
    • Coma
    • Hypothermia
    • Decreased pupillary light reflex
    • Nystagmus
    • Strabismus
    • Vertigo
    • Slurred speech
    • Ataxia
    • Decreased deep tendon reflexes
  • Psychiatric manifestations:
    • Impairment in thinking (delirium of any kind- cardinal feature)
    • Irritability
    • Combativeness
    • Paranoia
  • Respiratory manifestations:
    • Respiratory depression
    • Apnea
    • Hypoxia
    • ARDS
  • Cardiovascular manifestations:
    • Tachycardia
    • Bradycardia
    • Hypotension
    • Diaphoresis
    • Shock
  • Other manifestations:
    • Electrolyte and endocrine disturbances
    • Renal dysfunction
    • Gastrointestinal
    • reduced bowel sounds
    • Skin Barbiturate blisters (ie, bullous lesions found on hands, buttocks, knees)

questions.text: The care to provide painless shortening of life in a terminal illness is termed as:
questions.solution:
• Euthanasia: producing painless death of a person suffering from hopelessly incurable and painful disease.
  • Physician-assisted suicide (PAS) is the physician prescribing a drug or other action to facilitate a patient taking his/her own life, with the committed action taken by the patient.
  • Palliative care: The provision of reasonable medical and Nursing procedures for the relief of physical pain, discomfort or emotional and psychological suffering as well as providing food and water in terminally ill patients.

questions.text: A young woman presents to the OPD with progressively worsening right thumb and wrist pain. There is pain on pinching her thumb against her other fingers. Physical examination: mild swelling and tenderness over radial styloid process. Phalen maneuver is negative. Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
- Inflammation of the abductor pollicis longus + the extensor pollicis brevis at the radial styloid process tendon sheath: De Quervain tenosynovitis.

- Caused by repetitive twisting of wrist

- There is pain when grasping with thumb, extends radially along the wrist to the radial styloid process.

questions.text: About the anatomy of the pituitary gland, which of the following is true?

choices.text: Growth hormone is derived from proopiomelanocortin
Prolactin-secreting cells are majority of cells in anterior pituitary.
Posterior pituitary has dual arterial supply.

questions.solution:
- The pituitary gland:

- forms from the Rathke pouch embryonically blood supply:

- from superior and inferior hypophyseal arteries

questions.text: Warrant cases are punishable with imprisonment
questions.solution: - Warrant case is related to an offence punishable with death, life imprisonment or imprisonment for ≥ 2years, e.g. murder, dowry deaths, attempt to murder cases.

questions.text: Tissue biopsy for histopathological examination should be sent in:
questions.solution: All tissue biopsies, including organs like brain tissue, are preserved in formalin for future histopathological examination.

questions.text: A 31 year old female patient presents with a right parotid region swelling. Which one of the following structures does NOT lie within the parotid gland?
questions.solution:
- From superficial to deep, the structures within the parotid gland:

  • Facial nerve
  • Retromandibular vein
  • External carotid artery

- The marginal mandibular nerve: is a branch of the facial nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is not encountered or traversed during the insertion of a tracheostomy?
questions.solution:
- The structures that are encountered and divided to allow the insertion of the tracheostomy tube (superficial to deep):

- skin —> subcutaneous fat —> platysma muscle —> investing layer of deep cervical fascia —> strap muscles —> pretracheal fascia —> thyroid isthmus —> trachea.

questions.text: A 40 year old mother of two wants to prevent relapse as she is recovering from alcohol dependence. On investigation, she is found to have a medical history of a hypertensive crisis resulting in a stroke. Which of the following medications would be appropriate in this case?
questions.solution:
• Best risk to benefit ratio medications: Acamprosate and Naltrexone.
  • Acamprosate: inhibition of NMDA receptors
  • Naltrexone: an opioid antagonist, given as p/o or monthly injection
    • Acts by reducing activity in the dopamine-rich area of the brainstem (ventral tegmental area) —> reduces positive feelings associated with alcohol.

questions.text: Fetal blood from placenta is almost 80% oxygenated. But, mixture with unoxygenated blood at various points reduces this oxygen content. Which one of the following fetal vessels contains blood with the highest O2 content?
questions.solution:
- Mixture with unoxygenated blood from vitelline veins and inferior vena cava —> reduction of the oxygen content.

- This relatively high oxygen content —> directed by IVC valve —> directly through foramen ovale —> into left atrium —> hence prevention of admixture with oxygen-depleted blood entering right atrium from superior vena cava.

- Hence, the O2-saturated blood entering left ventricle and then into aortic arch, subclavian arteries, and common carotid arteries: have highest oxygen content

questions.text: Which one of the following would be interfered with on Inhibition of actin assembly by cytochalasins?
questions.solution:
- Cytochalasins:

- potent inhibitors of cell motility + cellular events that depend on actin assembly:

- cytokinesis: conducted by the actin-containing contractile ring

- phagocytosis

- formation of lamellipodia.

- Cytochalasins —> bind to plus end of actin filaments —> prevent further polymerization.

questions.text: Gene rearrangement of cytotoxic T cells occurs primarily in?
questions.solution:
- T cell gene rearrangement:

- occurs during education of T cells in thymus in fetal and early neonatal development

- T cell receptor (TCR): made of α and β chains

- Each chain with variable amino-terminal portion and constant carboxyl-terminal portion.

- These chains: encoded for by V, D, J, and C gene segments

- These segments which undergo rearrangement during development in the thymus.

questions.text: Merkel cells, modified epidermal cells, function primarily in which one of the following?

choices.text: Detection of texture and shape during active touch

questions.solution:
- Merkel cell:

- neuroendocrine cell

- modified keratinocyte

- Found where fine tactile sensation is critical, like fingertips

- Associated with an unmyelinated nerve ending —> forms a Merkel corpuscle (disk), required for two-point discrimination: ability to discriminate two closely placed points as separate

questions.text: An alcoholic man presents with severe epigastric pain, which radiates to his back. Amylase and lipase levels: elevated, diagnosis: acute pancreatitis. He has 6 Ranson’s criteria, including a PaO2 < 60 mm Hg, over 48 hours. CXR: bilateral pulmonary infiltrates, wedge pressure: low. What is required to make a diagnosis of ARDS?

choices.text: Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure > 18 mm Hg

questions.solution:
• Adult respiratory distress syndrome:
    • “shock lung” or “traumatic wet lung”
    • diagnosis made based on:
      • bilateral pulmonary infiltrates on CXR
      • PaO2/FiO2 ratio < 200
      • pulmonary wedge pressures < 18 mm Hg.

questions.text: A 30 year old insomniac reports difficulty both falling and staying asleep as she cannot calm her mind and states that she has always been a ‘worrier’. A diagnosis of generalized anxiety disorder is made. All of the following characteristics are common to this disorder EXCEPT:

choices.text: Episodic palpitations, shortness of breath lasting 30 minutes
Concomitant feelings of hopelessness and sadness

questions.solution:
• Generalized anxiety disorder (GAD):
    • persistent, excessive, and/or unrealistic worry
    • occurring on most days
    • persists for at least 6 months.
    • The worry is to a degree that it is uncontrollable and causes social impairment.
  • Associated physical symptoms:
    • tension
    • restlessness
    • impaired concentration
    • insomnia
    • being “on edge.”

questions.text: What is the best course of action for a 55 year old patient with glioblastoma multiforme in the right parietal lobe, who has experienced his first generalized tonic-clonic seizure?

choices.text: Initiate therapy only if additional seizures occur

questions.solution: Lamotrigine and valproic acid: best initial therapies for individuals with generalized seizures.

questions.text: The primary regulator of salivary secretion is?
questions.solution:
- The autonomic nervous system: primary regulator of salivary gland function

- The pancreas: regulated primarily by hormones [cholecystokinin and secretin].

- Parasympathetic fibers carry neural signals from salivatory nuclei of medulla and pons

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is evaluated as part of an executive physical examination. He has read about different screening procedures on the Internet and is interested in being screened for hemochromatosis. A 43 year old man wants to be screened for hemochromatosis after reading about it on the internet. He is healthy and takes a daily multivitamin. His father drank alcohol heavily and died of cirrhosis at 56 years of age. There is no other liver disease in his family. What is the most appropriate first step to screen this disorder?
questions.solution:
• Hereditary hemochromatosis:
    • iron overload initially without symptoms
    • then iron overload with symptoms
  • Symptoms include:
    • lethargy
    • arthralgia
    • change in skin color
    • loss of libido
    • diabetes mellitus
    • Cirrhosis
    • cardiac arrhythmias
    • infiltrative cardiomyopathy are later
  • Screening is done using transferrin saturation and serum ferritin levels to detect anemia and iron deficiency.

questions.text: A 70 year old man with a history of diabetes, renal insufficiency, and CAD, presents to the ER in septic shock from emphysematous cholecystitis. Sp02: 100% on 6-L nasal cannula oxygen delivery, Hb: 7.2 mg/dL. Venous SpO2: 58%. Which of the following will best improve his oxygen delivery?

choices.text: Transfer him to a hyperbaric chamber

questions.solution:
• Transfusion of 2 units of PRBCs: increases patient’s O2 delivery the most.
  • Mixed venous oxygen saturation: difference between oxygen delivered to tissues and oxygen taken up by tissues.
  • The formula for oxygen content (CaO2):

CaO2=1.36xHbxSaO2/100+0.0031xPaO2

  • But patient’s SpO2 is 100% —> so increasing inspired oxygen concentration won’t increase his oxygen delivery.

questions.text: In which of the following patients must sedatives, as premedication, be avoided?
questions.solution:
