• Sedatives: alleviate anxiety in hypertensive patients (preventing blood pressure elevations due to surgery-related anxiety), in patients with chronic alcohol abuse, and in children to maintain cooperation for anesthesia induction.
  • In neurosurgical patients: sedatives can possibly lead to —> depression of respiratory drive —> hypercarbia and increased ICP.

questions.text: Which of the following maintain the low pH in the vagina?

choices.text: Proton pump similar to parietal cells
Acid secretion from intracellular carbonic acid
Secretion of lactic acid by stratified squamous epithelium
Bacterial metabolism: glycogen to lactic acid

questions.solution:
- Low (4.0) pH of the vagina:

- Maintained by bacterial metabolism of glycogen to form lactic acid

- Vagina has stratified squamous epithelium which contain large accumulations of glycogen —> Glycogen released into vaginal lumen — > metabolized to lactic acid by commensal lactobacilli.

- Low pH inhibits growth of microorganisms, but not STD pathogens

questions.text: Potential causes of elevated LDL include all of the following, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• Secondary forms of elevated LDL:
    • hypothyroidism
    • nephrotic syndrome
    • cholestasis
    • acute intermittent porphyria
    • anorexia nervosa
    • hepatoma
    • drugs such as thiazides, cyclosporine, and carbamazepine.

questions.text: Which one of the following is a primary risk factor for difficult mask ventilation?

choices.text: Inability to bring mandibular incisors anterior to the maxillary incisors

questions.solution:
• Mask ventilation: difficult with anything that prevents face mask from forming an adequate seal with patient’s face (e.g a beard) or that which increases resistance to airflow between the mouth and larynx.
  • Factors associated with difficult mask ventilation:
    • Edentulousness
    • history of snoring
    • history of neck radiation
    • multiple attempts at laryngoscopy
    • male gender, obesity
    • Mallampati status ≥3

questions.text: In jaw dislocation, articular disk displacement after the articular tubercle of the temporomandibular joint results from excessive contraction and spasm of which of the following muscles?
questions.solution:
- The lateral pterygoid muscles: protract the jaw

- Superior head of the lateral pterygoid muscle —> insert onto anterior aspect of articular disk of temporomandibular joint and on the head of the mandible —> spasm of this muscle (a yawn) can cause dislocation of the mandible —> on pulling articular disk anterior to articular tubercle

questions.text: Failure of sixth aortic arch arteries to form would lead to loss of blood supply to which one of the following essential organs?
questions.solution:
- Branches of the arteries of the sixth aortic arches —> form pulmonary arteries.

- Left sixth arch artery —> forms ductusarteriosus

- The face and thyroid gland receive blood from —> facial and superior thyroid arteries (eventual derivatives of 2nd and 3rd aortic arch arteries)

- The upper digestive tract —> supplied by celiac and superior mesenteric arteries, derivatives of vitelline arteries

questions.text: A 29 year old new mother presents to the psychiatrist stating she is depressed, and appears to have postpartum blues, because she gave her child growth retardation, a short philtrum, thin upper lip, microcephaly, microphthalmia, short palpebral fissures, midface hypoplasia. Which is the most appropriate diagnosis of the mother, apart from postpartum blues?
questions.solution:
• Child shows classic signs of fetal alcohol syndrome.
  • Besides the mentioned symptoms, these children also present with:
    • delayed development
    • hyperactivity
    • attention deficits
    • learning disabilities
    • intellectual deficits
    • seizures

questions.text: A 32 year old man goes to the OPD with complaints of impaired ejaculation. He is on: perphenazine, digoxin, propranolol, methadone and periodic cannabis usage. What is the most likely cause of this patient’s problems with ejaculation?
questions.solution:
• Perphenazine:
    • known to cause impairment in ejaculation

questions.text: A man’s HIV test is positive, but he has no signs or symptoms of AIDS. In 25% of patients with a positive HIV test, which one of the following psychiatric diagnoses may develop?
questions.solution: Patients receiving a positive HIV test may need counseling for a wide variety of symptoms, including anxi- ety and depression, a syndrome like PTSD, concern about minor physical symptoms, and adjustment disorders, the latter of which can occur in as many as 25% of those given a positive diagnosis. Other issues may be wor- ries about telling friends and family, issues of guilt and self-esteem, worries about financial and work considerations, and the future of the medical condition itself.

questions.text: All of the following laboratory tests are consistent with a diagnosis of DKA, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
DKA HHS
Glucose, mg/dl 250-600 600-1200
Sodium meg/L 125-135 135-145
Potassium Normal to ↑ Normal
Osmolality mosms/ml 300-320 330-380(>350)
Plasma ketones ++++ +/-
Serum bicarbonate <15meg/L Normal to slightly ↓
Arterial pH 6.8-7.3 >7-3
Arterial pCO2 20:30 Normal
Anion gap ↑ Normal to slightly ↑

questions.text: In families of patients with schizophrenia, who are overtly hostile and overly controlling, the schizophrenic patient would be affected which of the following ways?

choices.text: Familial behaviors will lead to patient’s first break of disease

questions.solution:
• Frieda Fromm- Reichmann: believed schizophrenia was outcome of inadequate mother–child relationship (mother: aloof, overly protective, or hostile)
  • Subsequent studies of effect of expressed emotion (family members: expressing hostility and being overly controlling): lead to an increase in relapse rates.

questions.text: A man presents to the ER with numbness and weakness in his legs and feet. On exam: he is numb to the knees, with marked weakness in ankle dorsiflexion and plantar flexion; hepatosplenomegaly and a dark tan with no history of sun exposure. He has a history of diabetes and hypothyroidism. Which of the following tests are required to make his diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• POEMS (polyneuropathy, organomegaly, endocrinopathy, M-protein, and skin changes)
    • progressive sensorimotor polyneuropathy
    • diabetes mellitus (50%)
    • primary gonadal failure (70%)
    • Plasma cell dyscrasia
    • sclerotic bony lesions
    • hepatosplenomegaly
    • lymphadenopathy
    • hyperpigmentation.
  • Detection of an M-protein on serum electrophoresis would confirm this diagnosis.

questions.text: A 57 year old woman complains of progressive stiffening and right shoulder pain. Medical history: several episodes of bursitis of right shoulder, treated with NSAIDs and steroid injections; and diabetes mellitus. Physical examination: right shoulder is tender to touch, limited flexion, extension, and abduction of passive and active range of motion. RHint shoulder X-ray: osteopenia with no evidence of joint erosion or osteophytes. Most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Adhesive capsulitis
    • characterized by pain, restricted motion of the shoulder
    • Occurs in absence of intrinsic shoulder disease,
    • M/c in patients with previous bursitis or tendinitis and other systemic illnesses (diabetes mellitus)
    • Gold standard for diagnosis: arthrography with <15mL injectable contrast
    • Regress spontaneously within 1 to 3 years.

questions.text: Peak cortisol levels are seen at which of the following times of day?

A 30 year old runner presents with complaints of aching pain on lateral aspect of left knee, with a burning sensation reaching lateral aspect of left thigh. . She is training for a marathon and runs 80-100 kms/ week. Knee is not hot or swollen. Physical examination: point tenderness over lateral femoral condyle, that worsens on flexing knee. Which one of the following treatments would not be recommended for this patient?

choices.text: Assessment of the patient’s running shoes
Ibuprofen 600–800 mg, every 6 hours as required

questions.solution:
• The iliotibial band: thick connective tissue that runs along outer thigh from ilium to fibula
  • This band tightens or inflames —> pain over lateral femoral condyle of the knee —> leading to burning or aching pain radiating toward outer thigh.
  • Most often seen in runners
  • Glucocorticoid injection: alleviates pain, but running is strictly to be avoided for 2 weeks after injection (not appropriate as this patient is training for a marathon)

questions.text: In a 32 year old man, with progressive breast enlargement during the past 6 months, with no drug use, lab evaluation shows reduced LH and reduced testosterone. Further evaluation of this patient will include which of the following?
questions.solution:
• Pathologic gynecomastia:
    • when effective ratio of testosterone to estrogen is reduced due low testosterone production or increased estrogen production.
    • Low LH and testosterone levels: suggests either estrogen or hCG production.

questions.text: Best definition of ‘enthesitis’?

choices.text: Palpable vibratory/ crackling sensation with joint motion
Inflammation of saclike cavity near joint that reduces friction
Inflammation at site of tendinous or ligamentous insertion into bone
Inflammation of periarticular membrane lining joint capsule

questions.solution:
• Enthesopathy or enthesitis:
    • inflammation at site of tendinous or ligamentous attachment into bone.
    • Seen in patients with:
      • seronegativespondyloarthropathies
      • viral infections.

questions.text: All of the following statements are incorrect about osteoarthritis, except?

choices.text: MRI required to evaluate any other causes
There is direct stimulation of pain receptors in joint cartilage.
Osteoarthritis: is the 2nd MCC of arthritis
Synovial fluid WBC: <1000 cells/μL in osteoarthritis

questions.solution:
• Synovial fluid: >1000/μL
    • inflammatory arthritis
    • gout
    • pseudogout

questions.text: A 33 year old woman, with diagnosed cystic fibrosis and vitamin D deficiency with a T-score of –2.9 in the lumbar hip and spine, is started on initial treatment with alendronate: 70 mg/ week, cholecalciferol: 5000 U daily, and calcium carbonate: 1500 mg/day. When should the bone densitometry testing be repeated to assess therapy response in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Medications take several years to produce significant changes in bone mineral density (BMD)
  • Bone densitometry is to be repeated at intervals of >2 years.
  • Only further declines in BMD should prompt a change in regimen.

questions.text: Which one of the following statements about pulmonary sarcoidosis is true?

choices.text: Cutaneous involvement is more common than lung involvement
Pulmonary hypertension doesn’t respond to therapy in sarcoidosis.
Pulmonary infiltrates in sarcoidosis: an upper lobe process.

questions.solution:
• Lung involvement occurs in >90% of sarcoidosis patients
  • Infiltrates in sarcoidosis are mainly an upper lobe process.
  • Pulmonary arterial hypertension: seen in at least 5% of sarcoidosis patients.

questions.text: A woman presents to the ER with progressively severe abdominal pain, initially at umbilicus, now localized to her right lower quadrant. She reports vague loss of appetite for a day, with no bowel movements or vomiting. Temperature: 100.8°F and HR: 105 bpm. Abdomen: tender in right lower quadrant. Urine pregnancy test: negative. Imaging most likely to confirm her diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
- Acute appendicitis:

- anorexia

- vague periumbilical pain

- Pain localization to right lower quadrant

- Low-grade fever

- leukocytosis

- Nonenhanced + contrast-enhanced CT: superior to ultrasound or plain radiograph

- sensitivity of 0.94

- specificity of 0.95

- Findings:

- thickened appendix

- periappendiceal stranding

- presence of fecalith (image given below)

questions.text: Which one of the following infectious clinical syndromes does NOT typically cause vesicular lesions?
questions.solution:
• Vesicles of varicella:
    • “dewdrop” appearance
    • develop randomly about trunk, extremities, and face over 3–4 days
  • Herpes zoster:
    • occurs in single dermatome
    • appearance of vesicles preceded by pain for several days
  • Cold sores:
    • primary infection or reactivation of herpes simplex virus
    • Vesicles on or around lips (HSV-1) or genitals (HSV-2)
    • Vesicles on head and neck of young wrestlers (herpes gladiatorum), on the digits of healthcare workers (herpetic whitlow).
  • Rickettsialpox:
    • papule with a central vesicle —> forms 1- 2.5-cm painless crusted black eschar with erythematous halo + proximal adenopathy

questions.text: A 32 year old woman presents with B/L lower extremity edema, polyuria, moderate left-sided flank pain from 2 weeks ago. Examination: normal vital signs, normal blood pressure. 2+ edema: bilateral lower extremities. 24-hour urine collection: 3.5 g of protein. Urinalysis: proteinuria. Serum creatinine: 0.7 mg/dL. Renal vein thrombosis is suspected. What test would be chosen for evaluation?

choices.text: Ultrasound with Doppler for renal veins

questions.solution:
- Renal vein thrombosis:

- Occurs in patients with nephrotic syndrome with membranous glomerulopathy + oncologic disease.

- Clinical manifestations:

- fever

- lumbar tenderness

- leukocytosis

- hematuria

- Magnetic resonance venography: most sensitive + specific noninvasive form of imaging

questions.text: A 54 year old woman with chronic migraines and depression and chronic migraine presents with several months of dry mouth and dry eyes, photosensitivity and eye burning. On examination: dry, erythematous, sticky oral mucosa. All of the following tests would be positive in this patient EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• Sjögren syndrome:
    • dry mouth and eyes
    • primary, in this case
    • Antibodies to Ro/SS-A or La/SS-B
    • Sialometry: decreased production of saliva
  • Scl-70 antibody: associated with scleroderma, not positive in primary Sjögren syndrome.

questions.text: A 43 year old HIV-positive man, who is not on antiretroviral therapy, has a recent CD4 cell count of 43/μL. He presents: several nontender red, ulcerated plaques, two weeks of fever and malaise. Pathologic examination: lobular proliferations of small blood vessels —> lined by enlarged endothelial cells —> interspersed with mixed infiltrates of neutrophils and lymphocytes. Blood cultures: positive for Bartonella henselae. This patient’s skin lesions is caused by?
questions.solution:
• Bacillary angiomatosis:
    • infection with B henselae
    • occurs primarily in HIV-infected persons, CD4+ T-cell count: <100/μL
    • presents as:
      • cutaneous lesions: not painful, may be tan, red, or purple in color
      • Subcutaneous masses or nodules
      • superficial ulcerated plaques
      • verrucous growths are also seen.

questions.text: A 72 year old woman, with a recent diagnosis of small-cell lung cancer, now complains of headaches, and confusion. Metastatic disease to the brain is suspected. MRI: mass lesion in right parietal lobe. Which MRI technique would most accurately identify the extent of the edema surrounding the lesion?
questions.solution:
- T2 images: more sensitive for detecting demyelination, infarction, and chronic hemorrhage, edema.

- Fluid-attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR): a type of T2-weighted image which suppresses high-intensity signal of CSF

- FLAIR technique images: more sensitive to detecting water-containing lesions or edema than the standard spin images.

questions.text: A 42 year old man is evaluated for a year of recurrent bilateral ear swelling and his right ear has become floppy. On examination, the left ear: beefy red color and the pinna: tender and swollen. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Relapsing polychondritis:
    • Usually presents with recurrent painful swelling of ear
    • floppy ears
    • pinna is affected
    • earlobe is spared (no cartilage in the lobe)

questions.text: A 32 year old woman presents with a 5-day long widespread skin rash. She is also taking sulfa medication for recurrent cystitis. Skin biopsy: leukocytoclastic vasculitis of dermal venules. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Hypersensitivity angiitis:
    • broad spectrum of inflammatory lesions
    • reaction to foreign materials (like bacterial products or more commonly (sulfa) drugs).
    • Vascular lesions confined to skin: leukocytoclastic vasculitis/ cutaneous vasculitis/ cutaneous necrotizing venulitis

questions.text: An HIV+ teenager, not on therapy, complains of 2 weeks of progressive malaise with low-grade fevers and is unable to get out of bed to go to college. He doesn’t have cough or sputum. CXR shown below. A provisional diagnosis of TB is made. Which of the following forms of tuberculosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
- The chest radiograph shows:

- bilateral small, millet seed size nodular infiltrates

- consistent with disseminated/ miliary tuberculosis.

- Absence of a sufficient acquired immune response (patients with advanced HIV infection) —> disseminated or miliary disease may result

questions.text: A 24 year old woman reports that she develops symptoms annually during August to November. She complains of rhinitis with post nasal drip and cough, itchy and watery eyes. She take Loratadine 10 mg daily, which improves her symptoms. What is the most likely allergen in this case?
questions.solution:
• Allergic rhinitis: symptoms are due to pollen production by weeds, grasses, and trees.
  • The timing of the pollination: predicts seasonal severity of symptoms.

questions.text: On physical examination of a 2-day-old neonate: multiple blisters on trunk and extremities. Skin biopsy: separation of basal layer of epidermis from basement membrane, no inflammatory cells. Immunofluorescence microscopy: No antibody deposits. Most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Epidermolysis Bullosa:
    • Tendency to form blisters at sites of minor trauma
    • Mutations of genes encoding cytokeratin intermediate filaments
    • Cosmetically disturbing and sometimes debilitating, but not life threatening

questions.text: Presence of HepB e antigen signifies which of the following in a chronic hepatitis B virus infection?
questions.solution:
• In acute hepatitis B:
    • HBeAg positivity: usually transient.
  • Persistence of HBeAg for >3 months: development of chronic hepatitis B.
  • In chronic hepatitis B:
    • presence of HBeAg:
      • ongoing viral replication
      • increased infectivity

questions.text: All of the following statements about cardiac cirrhosis are false, except?

choices.text: AST and ALT levels: may mimic acute viral hepatitis.
Budd-Chiari syndrome: same as cardiac cirrhosis, clinically
Echocardiography: gold standard for diagnosing constrictive pericarditis
Veno-occlusive disease: often confused with cardiac cirrhosis

questions.solution:
• Severe right-sided heart failure —> may lead to chronic liver injury and cardiac cirrhosis.
  • Elevated venous pressure —> leads to congestion of the hepatic sinusoids, central vein and centrilobular hepatocytes —> Centrilobular fibrosis develops —> fibrosis extends outward from the central vein, not the portal triads.

questions.text:
A patient with Sjögren syndrome has the following lab findings:

plasma sodium: 139 mEq/L
chloride: 112 mEq/L
bicarbonate: 15 mEq/L
potassium: 3.0 mEq/L
pH: 6.0
sodium: 15 mEq/L
potassium: 10 mEq/L
chloride: 12 mEq/L

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Type I renal tubular acidosis (RTA)/ distal RTA:
    • distal nephron does not lower pH normally
    • associated with a urine pH >5.5
    • hypokalemia
    • lack of bicarbonaturia
  • Sjögren-associated type I RTA: associated with calcium phosphate stones and nephrocalcinosis.

questions.text: A young man is treated with induction chemotherapy for acute lymphoblastic leukemia. His initial WBC count prior to treatment: 156,000/μL. All of the following are possible expected complications during his treatment EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• Tumor lysis syndrome:
    • Occurs in patients undergoing chemotherapy for acute leukemias, Burkitt lymphoma.
    • Chemotherapeutic agents act on these cells—> massive tumor lysis resulting in release of intracellular ions and nucleic acids —> characteristic metabolic syndrome of hyperuricemia, hyperphosphatemia, hyperkalemia, and hypocalcemia.

questions.text: A 49 year old man with a BMI of 28.8 kg/m2 is diagnosed with obstructive sleep apnea. He has an apnea-hypopnea index of 42/hr and a minimum O2 saturation of 78%. Most appropriate initial therapy for this patient is which of the following?
questions.solution:
• OSAHS treatment: nasal CPAP.
  • CPAP:
    • delivers a set pressure sufficient to overcome the tendency of posterior oropharynx to collapse
    • pressure: generally from 5–15 cmH2O.

questions.text: A woman presents to the ER with acute shortness of breath. Helical CT: no evidence of pulmonary embolus, dilatation of the ascending aorta to 4.3 cm. All the following are linked with this finding EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• Aortitis and ascending aortic aneurysms: usually caused by cystic medial necrosis and mesoaortitis (elastic fibers damage of aortic wall with thinning and weakening).
  • Causes:
    • syphilis
    • tuberculosis
    • mycotic aneurysm
    • Takayasu arteritis
    • giant cell arteritis
    • rheumatoid arthritis
    • spondyloarthropathies (ankylosing spondylitis, psoriatic arthritis, reactive arthritis, Behçet disease)
    • Marfan syndrome
    • Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.
  • Not typical in systemic lupus erythematosus.

questions.text: The largest delay between symptom onset and appropriate therapy for patients with ST-segment elevation MI usually occurs in what time interval?

choices.text: Between pain onset and patient’s decision to ask for help
Between patient call and emergency team arrival
Between emergency team arrival and arrival at hospital
Between arrival at hospital and decision to start reperfusion therapy

questions.solution:
• Most non-hospital deaths from STEMI are due to the sudden development of ventricular fibrillation (in first 24 hours of symptom onset, 50% of which occur in the first hour).
  • Major elements of prehospital care of patients with STEMI include:
    1. recognition of symptoms by patient and prompt seeking of medical attention
    2. recognition of symptoms by patient and prompt seeking of medical attention
    3. expeditious transportation of patient to a health facility
    4. expeditious implementation of reperfusion therapy.

questions.text: On routine antenatal bloods, a 32 year old woman is found to be Rhesus negative. What is correct about the management of her pregnancy?

choices.text: Kleihauser test performed if vaginal bleeding later in pregnancy
only two doses of anti-D administered
if current pregnancy doesn’t have Rh negative implications, neither will the future pregnancies

questions.solution:
- The Rhesus status of the fetus: depends also on the partner’s blood type, not just the mother’s.

- Routine doses of anti-D are usually given at 28 and 34 weeks, but to be considered after every sensitizing event.

- The Kleihauer test: to determine the proportion of fetal cells within the maternal circulation, so helps determine anti-D dosage

questions.text: The best contraceptive in a 45 year old woman with a BMI of 40, who is a smoker with multiple fibroids, in a stable relationship with a complete family, and who has a past history of peritonitis is which one of the following?
questions.solution:
- Combined oral contraceptive pill: contraindicated if the patient has BMI of 40.

- Mirena: unlikely to fit in uterine cavity due to multiple fibroids.

- Hysteroscopic sterilization: difficult in due to multiple fibroids.

- Progesterone-only pill: as effective as oral contraceptive pill in women over the age of forty.

questions.text: The recommended management of an 88 year old woman with IHD and a procidentia of uterus is:
questions.solution:
- Shelf pessary: first line

- Vaginal hysterectomy: second line

- Total vaginal mesh: currently not recommended

- Pelvic floor exercises: no role in Grade 2 or more prolapse.

questions.text: The measurement of ovarian reserve is done best by which of the following hormones?
questions.solution:
- Anti-Müllerian hormone (AMH) levels:

- measured in blood

- proportional to number of small antral follicles.

- decrease with age

- undetectable in post-menopausal period

- represent quantity of ovarian follicle pool

- Useful marker of ovarian reserve

questions.text: All of the following are clinical signs and findings of the presence of ovulation, except?

choices.text: Increase in basal body temperature >0.5°F in second half of menstrual cycle
Estrogen peak during secretory phase of menstrual cycle

questions.solution:
Women who have regular monthly bleeding cycles that do not vary by >4 days generally have ovulatory cycles, but several other indicators include

  • The presence of mittelschmerz - midcycle pelvic discomfort due to rapid expansion of the dominant follicle during ovulation or premenstrual symptoms like breast tenderness, bloating, and food cravings.
  • Progesterone level >5 ng/mL 7 days before expected menses.
  • An increase in basal body temperature >0.5°F in the second half of the menstrual cycle,
  • Detection of urinary LH surge.
  • Estrogen levels are elevated at the time of ovulation and during the secretory phase of the menstrual cycle but are not useful in detection of ovulation.

questions.text: A 16 year old girl who is not sexually active presents with left iliac fossa pain. USG: 5 cm complex cyst on left ovary, MRI: fatty deposits, solid and calcified elements. The likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
- Thecal luteal cysts: complex, have blood clots but no solid elements.

- Fibromas: solid elements but no calcified deposits.

- Tubo-ovarian abscesses: mucopurulent complex nature

- Dermoid cyst: MRI findings of calcified elements, fatty deposits pathognomonic of a dermoid cyst.

questions.text: n increased risk in multiple pregnancy is not seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
- All physiological changes of pregnancy —> exacerbated in multiple pregnancy.

- Greater placental area —> placenta praevia, pre-eclampsia more likely.

questions.text: In the developmental progression from childhood through puberty to menopause, all of the following statements regarding levels of FSH and LH are true except?

choices.text: FSH is suppressed from birth to 20 months of age.
Increased LH during the neonatal year (birth to 20 months).
Decreased LH and FSH during childhood before puberty.
At the onset of puberty, GnRH drives pituitary FSH and LH levels.

questions.solution:
• After birth and the loss of placenta-derived steroids, gonadotropin levels rise.
  • FSH levels are much higher in girls than in boys.
  • This rise in FSH results in ovarian activation (evident on ultrasound) and increased inhibin B and estradiol levels.
  • By 12–20 months of age, the reproductive axis is again suppressed, and a period of relative quiescence persists until puberty.
  • At the onset of puberty, pulsatile GnRH secretion induces pituitary gonadotropin production.
  • In the early stages of puberty, LH and FSH secretion are apparent only during sleep, but as puberty develops, pulsatile gonadotropin secretion occurs throughout the day and night.
  • Gonadotropin levels are cyclic during the reproductive years and increase dramatically with the loss of negative feedback that accompanies menopause.

questions.text: Which of the following occurs first in majority of girls with normal pubertal development?
questions.solution:
• The first menstrual period (menarche) occurs relatively late in the series of developmental milestones that characterize normal pubertal development.
  • Menarche: preceded by appearance of pubic and then axillary hair (adrenarche) --> due to maturation of zona reticularis in adrenal gland and increased adrenal androgen secretion, (dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA))
  • Menarche: also preceded by breast development (thelarche).
  • Breast development: precedes appearance of pubic and axillary hair in approximately 60% girls.
  • The interval between the onset of breast development and menarche is approximately 2 years.

questions.text: Which of the following women has the lowest risk of breast cancer?

choices.text: A woman with menarche at 12 years, first child at 24 years, and menopause at 47 years
A woman with menarche at 14 years, first child at 17 years, and menopause at 52 years
A woman with menarche at 16 years, first child at 17 years, and menopause at 42 years
A woman with menarche at 16 years, first child at 32 years, and menopause at 52 years

questions.solution:
- Breast cancer risk:

- age of menarche

- age of first full-term pregnancy

- age of menopause

- The lowest risk patients: shortest duration of total menses (i.e., later menarche (age 16 years old or older) and earlier menopause (52 years)) + early first full-term pregnancy.

questions.text: A couple married for 5 years have been attempting to conceive a child for the last 12 months. Despite regular intercourse, they have not achieved pregnancy. They are both 32 years of age and have no medical problems. Neither of the partner is taking medications. Which of the following is the most common cause of infertility?
questions.solution:
• Infertility: inability to conceive after 12 months of unprotected intercourse
  • Male factors: approximately 25% of cases of infertility,
  • unexplained infertility: 17% of cases
  • female causes: 58% of infertility cases (Amenorrhea/ ovulatory dysfunction).
  • This is most frequently due to hypothalamic or pituitary causes or polycystic ovary syndrome.
  • Tubal defects and endometriosis are less common.

questions.text: A 36 year old woman attends for a routine dating scan. Which of the following pieces of information will not be possible to get from a dating scan?
questions.solution:
- Early ultrasound: more accurate in dating the pregnancy than use of LMP.

- Twin pregnancy: detected at dating scan

- Uterine abnormalities: (bicornuate uterus) are best seen at this stage before cavity becomes too distended.

questions.text: A 33 years old woman with diabetes mellitus, renal insufficiency, and hypertension presented to the hospital with seizures during week 38 of her pregnancy. Her blood pressure is 165/95 mm Hg. She has 4+ proteinuria. Management should include all of the following except?
questions.solution:
• This patient has preeclampsia with severe features, and delivery should be performed as rapidly as possible.
  • In mothers at <34 weeks of gestation, corticosteroids should be administered for fetal benefit and delivery delayed 24–48 hours if possible .
  • Aggressive management of blood pressure, usually with labetalol or hydralazine intravenously, decreases maternal risk of stroke.
  • Eclamptic seizures should be controlled with magnesium sulfate, which has been shown to be superior to phenytoin and diazepam in large randomized clinical trials.

questions.text: You are seeing a 36 year old woman in clinic as her family practitioner. In her history, she reports no illness and is taking no medications. She does mention that she and her husband have been trying to conceive a child for the past 7 months but have been unsuccessful. Which of the following would be an appropriate response?

choices.text: “You have likely entered menopause and cannot have a child.”
“We do not recommend evaluation by a fertility specialist until you and her husband have tried for at least 12 months.”
“I will refer you to an expert in fertility issues.”
“Most causes of infertility are related to the male. I suggest you have him evaluated.”

questions.solution:
• Infertility can be attributed primarily to male factors in 25% of couples and female factors in 58% of couples and is unexplained in about 17% of couples.
  • Not uncommonly, both male and female factors contribute to infertility.
  • Decreases in the ability to conceive as a function of age in women have led to recommendations that women >34 years old who are not at increased risk of infertility seek attention after 6 months, rather than 12 months as suggested for younger women, and receive an expedited workup and approach to treatment.

questions.text: A 28 years old woman presented with longstanding type 1 diabetes on insulin. She tells you that she and her husband have decided to try to conceive. Which of the following is true regarding reproductive issues and diabetes?

choices.text: Women with diabetes have a reduced reproductive capacity.
Insulin crosses the placenta and may affect the fetus adversely.
The patient should expect her insulin requirements to increase during pregnancy.
High maternal serum glucose increases the risk of fetal abnormalities.

questions.solution:
• Reproductive capacity in either men or women with diabetes mellitus appears to be normal.
  • Glucose, which at high levels is a teratogen to the developing fetus, readily crosses the placenta, but insulin does not.
  • Thus, hyperglycemia from the maternal circulation may stimulate insulin secretion in the fetus.
  • The anabolic and growth effects of insulin may result in macrosomia.
  • The most crucial period of glycemic control is soon after fertilization.
  • The risk of fetal malformations is increased 4–10 times in individuals with uncontrolled diabetes at the time of conception.
  • Normal plasma glucose during the preconception period and throughout the periods of organ development in the fetus should be the goal.

questions.text: A 26 years old woman is in her last trimester of a normal pregnancy. Synthesis of milk by her mammary glands specifically requires which of the following?
questions.solution:
• The mammary gland enlarges during pregnancy in response to several hormones, including prolactin synthesized by the anterior pituitary not by the corpus luteum, estrogen and progesterone synthesized by the corpus luteum, and placental lactogen.
  • Oxytocin is required for the release of milk from the mammary gland through the action of the myoepithelial cells that surround the alveoli.
  • However it is not required for milk synthesis.
  • Arginine Vasopressin binds to receptors in the collecting tubules of the kidney and promotes resorption of water into the circulation.

questions.text:
A 32 years old G2P1 female presents to her obstetrician with abdominal discomfort, increased back pain, shortness of breath, and swelling in her feet and ankles.
Ultrasound reveals an amniotic fluid index (AFI) of 27 cm. The condition is caused by which of the following?

choices.text: Precocious development of the swallowing reflex in the fetus

questions.solution:
• An amniotic fluid index of 27 cm is indicative of polyhydramnios.
  • Duodenal and/or esophageal atresia result in an inability of the fetus to swallow amniotic fluid.
  • The result is that normal recirculation of amniotic fluid through the embryo is greatly reduced or eliminated, causing an excess of amniotic fluid.
  • Low volumes of amniotic fluid (oligohydramnios) are caused by rupture of the fetal membranes, bilateral agenesis of the kidneys, or obstructive uropathy.
  • Hypoplasia of the lungs and compression of the umbilical cord are associated with oligohydramnios, but do not cause it.
  • Less urine output = less amniotic fluid; less swallowing = more amniotic fluid.

questions.text: A woman is 24 weeks pregnant with her first child. She developed cellulitis in the right leg and requires antibiotic treatment. Which of the following antibiotics should not be used during the second and third trimesters of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The FDA has a classification system that designates the safety of drugs in pregnancy.

Class A

  • Safety of the drug without effects on the fetus.
  • No antibiotic is designated as a class A drug in pregnancy.

Class B

  • No effects in animal reproduction, or if the animal data show effects, adequate data in pregnant women to show these drugs can be safely used.
  • Antibitoics include azithromycin, cephalosporins, clindamycin, meropenem, penicillins, and vancomycin.

Class C

  • More potential risks, but one has to determine if the potential benefits to the health of the mother warrant use despite the potential risk.
  • Antibiotics include fluoroquinolones and linezolid.

Class D

  • Some degree of fetal risk and should be avoided if other safer alternatives exist.
  • Antibitoics include Sulfonamides and tetracyclines
  • The specific concern for use of doxycycline in the second and third trimester is discoloration of the teeth in the fetus.

questions.text: A 16 week pregnant 24 year-old woman is seen for routine follow-up of an uncomplicated pregnancy. What is the recommended screening and treatment of asymptomatic bacteriuria in this particular patient?

choices.text: Screen and treated in 3rd trimester only.
Screened with urine culture, not treated unless symptomatic.
Screened at 16wks and treated if culture is positive.

questions.solution:
• Asymptomatic bacteriuria (ASB):
    • without local or systemic symptoms of infection
    • presents with bacteria in the urine
    • diagnostic cutoff:
      • >105 colony-forming units (CFU)/mL in spontaneously voiding patients
      • >102 CFU/mL in catheterized individuals who have a catheter.
    • In pregnant women: screening and treatment of ASB recommended due to increased risk of:
      • preterm birth
      • perinatal death of fetus
      • pyelonephritis in mother.

questions.text: The following are traditional contraindications for oral HRT in postmenopausal women EXCEPT:

choices.text: CHD risk over future 10 years of 5%–10%

questions.solution:
• Traditional contraindications for oral hormone replacement therapy:
    • unexplained vaginal bleeding
    • active liver disease
    • history of venous thromboembolism due to pregnancy
    • oral contraceptive use
    • blood clotting disorder
    • history of breast or endometrial cancer
    • diabetes.
  • Ten-year risk of coronary heart disease: with a risk of 5%–10% —> not a traditional contraindication for oral HRT.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presented to your clinic. On examination you are seeing the findings (as given in the image below). What is your diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
The image shows 'tram line' bruising most likely to have been produced by a stick or a broom handle.

Tramline bruise:·

  • When a person hit with a stick, tramline bruise is produced·
  • It is also known as railway line bruise

Ectopic bruise:·

  • Bruise away from site of impact.·
  • Eg: Battle's sign, in a case of middle cranial fossa fracture

Six penny bruise:·

  • It is seen in manual strangulation (Throttling) i.e. compression of neck by hand.

Butterfly bruise:·

  • It is produced by skin pinching; seen in child abuse.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Cephalhematoma?

choices.text: Its size is maximum at birth
It is due to hemorrhage in the layers of scalp

questions.solution:
• Cephalhematoma : subperiosteal hemorrhage, limited by periosteum.
  • Take 24-48 hours to appear completely & 6-7 weeks to disappear
